- Check your SFU email regularly for enrolment appointment details; do not forward your SFU email (you may miss important messages or experience delivery issues).
- To be eligible to enrol, your goSFU student account must be in good standing. Fee waivers or School Associate certificates do not cover student activity fee, student services fee, recreation‑athletic fee, U‑Pass BC fee, or health‑dental plan fee.
- To opt out of SFSS Health and/or Dental, go to www.studentcare.ca and provide proof of equivalent group benefits (benefits card copy or employer letter).
- After enrolling or making class changes, view your account in goSFU → Finances / Account Summary; fees are recalculated immediately and class drop penalties are posted during the third week of classes.
- All fees are detailed in the Academic Calendar (see Undergraduate or Graduate fees).
- For official stamped statements, bring the copy(ies) to the Registrar and Information Services desk at any of the three campuses.
- For inquiries about transactions or account questions, email Student Accounts.
- Outstanding fees must be paid by the term due date; a 2% monthly interest charge (18% per annum) applies to outstanding balances. Holds from outstanding fees prevent future enrolment, ordering official transcripts, or requesting degrees/diplomas/certificates; payment in full must be reflected on your goSFU account to lift the hold.
- Accounts not fully paid by the tuition payment deadline incur a 2% monthly interest charge assessed on the first of each month.
- To view charges and payments: goSFU → Student Centre → Finances → Account Inquiry → Activity → “view all.”
- To print an official receipt, use the toggles under “Printing your Student Account Summary/Official receipt” in the Check your account section.
- SFU address: 8888 University Drive, Burnaby, B.C., Canada V5A 1S6.
- Land acknowledgement: Simon Fraser University respectfully acknowledges the xʷməθkʷəy̓əm (Musqueam), Sḵwx̱wú7mesh Úxwumixw (Squamish), səlilwətaɬ (Tsleil‑Waututh), q̓íc̓əy̓ (Katzie), kʷikʷəƛ̓əm (Kwikwetlem), Qayqayt, Kwantlen, Semiahmoo and Tsawwassen peoples.

- Payments can take time to post: Flywire timing depends on method; internet banking usually 2–3 business days; in‑person payments post immediately. If paid on the tuition deadline, interest won’t apply if you can provide proof of payment date.
- Payment options: internet banking (recommended for Canadian accounts), Flywire (international), goSFU online with Visa/MasterCard, or in‑person at RIS counters with Canadian debit card or personal cheque; digital wallets are not accepted at counters. Flywire Payment Plans are available but do not waive monthly interest on unpaid balances.

Question: Will payments made on the tuition deadline date incur the 2% monthly interest charge?
Answer:

Accepted payment options (summary)

- Admission deposit is non‑refundable/non‑transferable ($250 Canadian undergrad; $5,000 international undergrad; graduate amounts vary).

Question: Who is automatically enrolled in the SFSS Health and Dental Plan?

Answer:
Distance Education students
New students starting their studies in the Summer term
Certain other categories of students

Question: When does the SFSS Health and Dental Plan run and how is coverage prorated?
Answer: Runs from September to August of the following year, and coverage is prorated for students who begin their studies at SFU in the Spring term.

Question: How can I check my Health and Dental Plan enrolment status?
Answer:
Check your fee statement on goSFU.
Contact Studentcare for assistance.

Question: Where do I go to self-enrol if I am not automatically enrolled?

Question: When is the Change-of-Coverage Period and where are the deadlines published?
Answer:
During the term's Change-of-Coverage Period (specific dates vary by term).  
Deadlines are published at studentcare.ca.

Question: How do I opt out of the SFSS Health and Dental Plan?
Answer:
1. During the term’s Change-of-Coverage period, go to studentcare.ca and log in.  
2. Find the Opt-Outs section and submit proof of equivalent extended health/dental coverage.  
3. Meet the opt-out deadline published at studentcare.ca.  
4. Wait for a confirmation email from studentcare.ca—you must receive this to have the fees removed.  
5. Repeat the opt-out process every year (or log in during the period to confirm you still want to opt out if you previously submitted proof).

Question: What proof of coverage is required to opt out of the Health and Dental Plan?
Answer: Proof of equivalent extended coverage submitted to Studentcare (e.g., BC MSP or another eligible insurance plan).

Question: Do I need to opt out every year even if I opted out previously?
Answer: Yes — you must opt out every year. If you provided proof previously, log in to studentcare.ca during the Change-of-Coverage period and indicate you still want to opt out.

Question: How can Professional Development Program (PDP) students opt in or opt out of coverage?
Answer:
Opt in — During the term's Change-of-Coverage Period via studentcare.ca (Self‑Enrolment).

Opt out — During the term's Change-of-Coverage Period via studentcare.ca (Opt‑Outs).

Question: Who is automatically enrolled in the GSS Health and Dental Plan?
Answer: Graduate students (excluding Distance Education students, new students starting in the Summer term, and certain other categories)

Question: Which graduate students are excluded from automatic enrolment in the GSS plan?
Answer:
Distance Education students
New students starting their studies in the Summer term
Certain other categories of students

Question: How do opt-out procedures for graduate students differ from undergraduate students?
Answer: They do not differ in procedure — both must opt out each year during the Change-of-Coverage period via studentcare.ca by providing proof of equivalent extended coverage and meet the published deadlines. The only difference is the plan name (undergrads: SFSS Health & Dental; grads: GSS Health & Dental).

Question: Who is enrolled in the mandatory guard.me@SFU plan for new international students?
Answer:
New international students enrolled in an undergraduate program at SFU
New international students enrolled in a graduate program at SFU
New international students enrolled in an exchange program (including those on exchange or studying abroad)
International students at the Great Northern Way Campus and the Centre for Digital Media
International students who previously attended SFU and were absent for three or more consecutive terms
International students readmitted under SFU's reactivation and readmission policy

Question: When must new international students apply for BC Medical Services Plan (MSP)?
Answer: If they will reside in British Columbia for longer than six months.

Question: Which campuses and programs are covered by the guard.me@SFU plan?

Programs: Undergraduate; Graduate; Exchange

Campuses: Great Northern Way Campus; Centre for Digital Media

Question: Which previously-attending or readmitted international students are enrolled in guard.me@SFU?
Answer: International students who previously attended SFU and were absent for three or more consecutive terms, and those readmitted under SFU's reactivation and readmission policy.

Question: How can I opt out of the guard.me@SFU plan if I already have BC MSP or another eligible plan?
Answer:
Submit proof of BC MSP or another eligible insurance to guard.me@SFU to request an opt‑out (follow the opt‑out instructions on the SFU medical insurance page).  
Visit www.guard.me/sfu or www.sfu.ca/medical-insurance.html to upload documentation and complete the opt‑out.  
If seeking a partial refund, apply to guard.me@SFU before the last month of the term (April 1, August 1, or December 1).  
For assistance call guard.me at 905‑752‑6230 (within Canada) or 1‑888‑756‑8428 (toll‑free).

Question: Under what conditions am I eligible for a refund of unused guard.me@SFU insurance?
Answer:
- You have not made any claims on the guard.me@SFU policy.  
- There is more than one month of coverage remaining when you apply.  
- You apply to guard.me@SFU before the last month of the term (application deadlines: April 1, August 1, or December 1).

Question: What are the deadlines to apply for a partial reimbursement from guard.me@SFU?
Answer: April 1, August 1, December 1

Question: How will an approved partial refund from guard.me@SFU be credited?
Answer: The partial refund will be credited to your SFU account.

Question: What are the contact details for guard.me@SFU for plan details and inquiries?

www.guard.me/sfu
905-752-6230 (within Canada)
1-888-756-8428 (toll-free outside of Canada)

Question: How do I get Health and Dental Plan charges removed from my SFU account?
Answer:
Yes: If you received a confirmation email from studentcare.ca that you successfully opted out, ignore the HDP charges and pay your balance minus the HDP charges (monthly interest will not apply to the opted-out amounts).

No: If you did not opt out during the change-of-coverage period (or did not receive a confirmation), you are responsible for the HDP charges and must pay the full balance.

Question: If I received an email confirming I successfully opted out, what should I do about my account balance?
Answer: Pay your balance minus the Health and Dental Plan (HDP) charges — you may ignore those HDP charges.

Question: What happens if I did not opt out during the change-of-coverage period?
Answer:
You are responsible for the Health and Dental Plan charges and must pay the full balance.  
If you did not receive an email from studentcare.ca confirming a successful opt-out, then you have not opted out and must pay the charges.

Question: Will monthly interest charges be applied to amounts I successfully opted out of?
Answer: No. If you received an email from studentcare.ca confirming you successfully opted out, monthly interest will not be charged on the opted-out amounts.

Question: Where will the full exam schedule be posted?
Answer:
Over the past five undergraduate surveys, roughly one third of students said they could not enrol in a required course – and an exam conflict with another course ranked as one of the top three reasons. By producing the exam schedule after enrolment, we will eliminate enrolment/exam enrolment conflicts completely.

Previously, due to the early release, many departments scheduled exams “just in case”. As a result, each term nearly 20% of scheduled exams were cancelled or modified to a different format. That meant that 20% of available exam blocks were wasted. By changing to a later release, we’ll be able to use all of the exam blocks to the fullest extent possible, and spread exams more evenly.

Our goal is to reduce hardship through the entire student body, and we will be transparent with the results and numbers this new process produces as we move forward.

Students should check goSFU during the second month of the term. If a course has an exam, it will show up in goSFU. The full exam schedule will also be posted on the exams website when ready.

Answer: The Academic Progress Report (APR) is a powerful report and planning tool that informs advisors and undergraduate students of how far along a student is in obtaining their degree.

Question: How does the APR help advisors and undergraduate students?
Answer:
- Informs advisors and undergraduate students how far along a student is in obtaining their degree.  
- Lets advisors run What‑If reports to simulate how courses might transfer into a different program.  
- Enables students to plan courses in advance and enroll using My Planner; advisors can view the student's planned courses and collaborate on planning.

Question: Can the APR be used to evaluate how courses might transfer into a different program?
Answer: Yes — an advisor can use the APR’s "What‑If" report to simulate transfers; students cannot run What‑If reports themselves.

Question: How can a student explore transfer scenarios using the APR?
Answer:
Make an appointment with an advisor.  
The advisor will run a What‑If report to simulate a hypothetical program summary.  
Students cannot run What‑If reports themselves.

Question: Who can run a What-If report to simulate a hypothetical summary?
Answer: An advisor

Question: Can students run a What-If report themselves?
Answer: No

Question: What is the My Planner feature within the APR?
Answer: A feature that lets students plan courses in advance and use their planner to enrol in courses; advisors can view a student’s planned courses and work with them but cannot add courses to the student’s My Planner.

Question: Can students use My Planner to enroll in courses?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Can an advisor place courses into a student’s My Planner?
Answer: No — advisors cannot add courses to a student’s My Planner; they can only view the student’s planned courses and assist with planning.

Question: Can an advisor view a student’s planned courses in My Planner?
Answer: Yes

Question: What is the Academic Progress Report (APR)?
Answer: The Academic Progress Report (APR) is an interactive course mapping tool designed to help current undergraduate students understand their degree and program requirements, and to provide a starting place for making informed decisions about their academic program.

Question: Who is the APR designed to help?
Answer: Current undergraduate students

Question: How does the APR help students understand their degree and program requirements?
Answer: It is an interactive course-mapping tool that shows degree and program requirements and provides a starting place for making informed decisions about students’ academic programs.

Question: Is the APR an interactive course mapping tool?
Answer: Yes

Question: Which programs are not available through the APR?
Answer: Not provided in the context.

Question: Does the APR replace Individual Academic Planning or consultations with an Academic Advisor?
Answer: No — APR does not replace Individual Academic Planning or consultations with an Academic Advisor.

Question: Can the APR be used for Course Planning, Degree Planning, or Graduation Checks without an advisor?
Answer: No — APR does not replace Individual Academic Planning; Course Planning, Degree Planning, and Graduation Checks should be done in consultation with an Academic Advisor.

Question: How do I access the APR?
Answer:
Current undergraduate students: sign in using your SFU computing ID through a secure connection.

For assistance, contact Registrar and Information Services via LiveHelp (Launch liveHelp).

Question: How can I use the APR to plan my courses?
Answer:
- Use the APR to view and understand your degree and program requirements.  
- Map your completed, in‑progress, and planned courses to those requirements to see which are satisfied and which remain.  
- Build and adjust a term‑by‑term course plan interactively to explore different course choices and sequences.  
- Use the APR as a starting point for making informed decisions about your program.  
- Consult an Academic Advisor for formal course planning, degree planning, and graduation checks — the APR does not replace individual academic advising.

Question: How do I access and print my Confirmation of Enrolment letter through goSFU?
Answer:
1. Log in to your student account via the web version of goSFU and go to your Student Center.  
2. Under Academics / Other Academic, open the drop-down menu and select "Confirmation of Enrolment"; choose the From and To Term as needed and click Go.  
3. The Confirmation of Enrolment will be produced as a PDF and emailed to your SFU email account (you can print it from there).

Question: Can I only access the Confirmation of Enrolment letter using the web version of goSFU?
Answer: Yes — the Confirmation of Enrolment letter is available via the goSFU web version only.

Question: Which menu option in Student Center do I use to get a Confirmation of Enrolment?
Answer: Academics / Other Academic → Confirmation of Enrolment

Question: How do I select the term range for my Confirmation of Enrolment letter?
Answer: The most recent term is selected by default; choose any *From and *To Term from the drop‑down menus in your Student Center Confirmation of Enrolment page and click the Go button.

Question: Will the Confirmation of Enrolment letter be emailed to me or downloaded immediately?
Answer: It’s produced as a PDF and emailed to your SFU email account (not downloaded directly).

Question: Can I access Confirmation of Enrolment letters for previous or multiple terms?
Answer: Yes. You can access Confirmation of Enrolment letters for previous or multiple terms through the web version of goSFU (your Student Centre).

Question: What information is included on the undergraduate Confirmation of Enrolment letter?
Answer:
- Student name
- SFU student number
- Program and degree
- Enrolment status (full‑time/part‑time) and term(s) of enrolment
- Registered courses and credits/units
- Projected completion date
- Date of issue
- SFU letterhead and embedded security/authentication features

Question: Why does the graduate version list fewer items than the undergraduate letter?
Answer: The graduate letter includes only essential enrolment details because many undergraduate-specific items (e.g., majors/minors, certain program requirements or course listings) don’t apply to individualized graduate programs. Graduate records are managed differently, so the template is pared down to the information that is relevant and verifiable for graduate students.

Follow the instructions on the pop‑up blocker help page.  
If the issue persists, contact 778-782-6930 or email reginfo@sfu.ca.

Question: Who do I contact if I still can’t view the PDF after checking browser settings?

Question: Is the Confirmation of Enrolment letter I download considered an official document?
Answer: Yes. The confirmation of enrolment letter you download is an official SFU document and includes embedded security features to verify its authenticity.

Question: What security features are embedded in the Confirmation of Enrolment letter?
Answer: Not specified — the text only states the letter "includes embedded security features" to help staff verify its authenticity.

Question: My projected completion date is incorrect—what steps should I take?
Answer:
1. Schedule a meeting with your department or faculty advisor to request a program extension.
2. Your advisor will submit a Program Extension Form to the Registrar and Information Services Office on your behalf.
3. After the form is reviewed, you will be notified of any applicable fees via your SFU email. These fees must be paid before your request for a letter can be processed.
4. Once the fees are settled, a custom Confirmation of Enrolment letter will be emailed to you or made available for pickup within five business days.

Question: How does the Program Extension process work and who needs to submit the form?
Answer:
Process: Schedule a meeting with your department or faculty advisor to request the extension. Your advisor will submit the Program Extension Form to the Registrar and Information Services Office; after review you’ll be notified of any fees, which must be paid before a custom Confirmation of Enrolment letter is issued (available by email or pickup within five business days). This does not update the online COE.

Who submits the form: Your department or faculty advisor submits the Program Extension Form on your behalf (you must request it by meeting with the advisor).

Question: Will the online Confirmation of Enrolment be updated after a program extension is processed?
Answer: No — the online Confirmation of Enrolment is not updated after a program extension; a custom COE will be emailed or made available for pickup once fees are paid and the request is processed.

Question: How long does it take to receive a custom Confirmation of Enrolment letter after paying fees?
Answer: Within five business days after fees are paid.

Question: How do I confirm my enrolment with Student Loans?
Answer:
Visit the Student Loans website for instructions on confirming your enrolment.  
Do NOT use the SFU Confirmation of Enrolment letter for Student Loans.

Question: Should I use the SFU Confirmation of Enrolment letter to confirm enrolment for student loans?
Answer: No. You should NOT use an SFU Confirmation of Enrolment letter for student loans — follow the Student Loans website/process for confirming enrolment.

Question: I’ve been reactivated but cannot enrol yet—how do I get a letter confirming my student status for a study permit/visa?
Answer: Please submit a Confirmation of Enrolment request form and indicate in the Additional Comments section that you have been reactivated. SFU staff will contact you to confirm your situation and arrange for the necessary documents.

Question: How do I obtain a letter to confirm enrolment for RESP purposes?
Answer:
- Log in to the web version of goSFU: Student Center → Academics / other academic → Confirmation of Enrolment → select term(s) → Go. The COE is produced as a PDF and emailed to your SFU email account (you can also download/print it).

- Use the SFU Confirmation of Enrolment letter for RESP redemption — current RESP providers will accept it; verify your provider’s specific requirements.

- If your RESP provider is not listed or requires an external form, contact Registrar and Information Services (submit a Custom Letter and Form Request / request completion of the external form). External form completion fee = $20 (+PST).

Question: Is there a charge for a standard Confirmation of Enrolment letter?
Answer: No — there is no charge for standard Confirmation of Enrolment letters available through your Student Centre.

Question: What are the fees for custom Confirmation of Enrolment letters and special letter requests?
Answer:
Custom Confirmation of Enrolment Letters (up to 3 terms) = $15 (+PST)

Special Letter Requests = $25 (+PST)

Question: Can SFU confirm enrolment for a future term?
Answer: No. SFU cannot confirm enrolment for future terms. They may indicate an undergraduate student’s eligibility to enrol in a future term — submit a "Custom Letter and Form Request." You will be notified of any applicable fee via your SFU email; payment must be made before processing. Custom letters will not be issued to students with a financial hold.

Question: How do I request a custom letter or completion of an external form?
Answer:
- Submit a "Custom Letter and Form Request."
- Upload the external form (if applicable) and specify any additional information in the Additional Comments section.
- You will be contacted via your SFU email to confirm details and to be informed of any applicable fees; payment must be made before processing.
- Allow at least five business days for processing.
- Custom letters will not be issued to students with a financial hold.
- Fees: Completion of external forms = $20 (+PST). Custom Confirmation of Enrolment Letters = $15 (+PST). Special letter requests (e.g. 3+ terms, other services) = $25 (+PST).

Question: How long will it take to process a custom letter or external form request?
Answer: Please allow at least five business days for processing your request.

Question: Will custom letters be issued if I have a financial hold on my student account?
Answer: No. Custom letters will not be issued to students who have a financial hold on their accounts.

Question: Can someone else request a Confirmation of Enrolment letter on my behalf?
Answer: No. Only the student can request their own Confirmation of Enrolment letter. Third parties (parents, guardians, sponsors) are not permitted to request it on the student's behalf.

Question: What should international students carry to prove their enrolment status when entering Canada?
Answer: A current SFU confirmation of enrolment letter (and consult International Student Advising and Programs for any other required immigration documents).

Answer: English is the primary language of instruction and assessment at SFU. You can download a letter to demonstrate this.

Question: I’m having difficulty viewing the PDF — what should I try first?

Question: How do I turn off a pop-up blocker to view the PDF?
Answer:
Google Chrome (desktop)
- Click the three dots (⋮) → Settings → Privacy and security → Site Settings → Pop-ups and redirects.
- Toggle to “Allowed” or click Add and enter https://go.sfu.ca (or click the lock icon in the address bar → Site settings → Pop-ups and redirects → Allow).
- Refresh the page.

Firefox (desktop)
- Menu (☰) → Settings → Privacy & Security → Permissions → Block pop-up windows.
- Uncheck to disable blocking entirely or click Exceptions… and add https://go.sfu.ca.
- Refresh the page.

Microsoft Edge (desktop)
- Settings and more (…) → Settings → Cookies and site permissions → Pop-ups and redirects.
- Toggle to “Allowed” or click Add under Allow and enter https://go.sfu.ca.
- Refresh the page.

Safari (macOS)
- Safari → Settings/Preferences → Websites → Pop-up Windows.
- Find the current site and set to Allow, or set “When visiting other websites” to Allow to disable globally.
- Refresh the page.

Chrome on Android
- Chrome menu → Settings → Site settings → Pop-ups and redirects.
- Toggle to Allowed or add https://go.sfu.ca under Allowed.
- Refresh the page.

Safari on iPhone/iPad
- Settings app → Safari → toggle off Block Pop-ups.
- Return to Safari and refresh the page.

If enabling pop-ups doesn’t work, disable any ad‑blocker/extension temporarily and try again.

Question: How do I obtain my SFU parchment if I graduated?
Answer:
- You should have received your parchment at your Convocation ceremony or had it mailed afterwards.

- To replace or request additional copies: complete the Parchment Replacement Form, include your student number and your signature, and pay the required fees. All outstanding accounts must be cleared before release.

- If you don’t know your student number, request it via the SFU alumni student-number request form.

- Do not request parchments by phone. For email requests: make payment via internet banking before emailing the signed form to urecords@sfu.ca (do NOT email credit card details).

- In person: order or pick up at Registrar & Information Services counters (Burnaby, Surrey, Vancouver) with photo ID. Cash is not accepted at counters; pay by cheque, debit (in person), Visa or MasterCard.

- Processing: requests are processed monthly on the 15th (payments must be received before the 15th). Rush processing (additional $50 + $3.50 PST) is available only in person or by fax and guarantees processing within five business days; rush does not include parchment cost or priority delivery.

- For rush verification or general inquiries contact Undergraduate Records at 778.782.6930 or phone 778.782.4969.

- Pickup: you will be emailed when your parchment is ready; photo ID required. You can authorize a third party via a Privacy Service Indicator in Student Center or a signed letter of authorization (the third party must show photo ID).

- Mailing: priority/courier (Canada Post Xpresspost) is available for an additional charge and provides tracking.

Question: What should I do if I need to replace my parchment?
Answer:
1. Complete the Parchment Replacement Form.  
2. Include your student number and sign the form (if you don’t know your student number, request it via SFU alumni student-number request).  
3. Ensure all outstanding accounts are cleared.  
4. Pay in full (cheque, Visa or MasterCard; debit accepted in person; or internet banking prior to emailing the form). Do NOT email credit card information.  
5. Submit the form by email to urecords@sfu.ca, by mail, fax, or in person at the Registrar & Information Services counters (Burnaby, Surrey, Vancouver).  
6. If you need rush processing, request in person or by fax (rush $50 + $3.50 PST; not available for email/mail) and contact Undergraduate Records to verify (778‑782‑6930).  
7. Provide photo identification to pick up the parchment; to authorize a third party, add a Privacy Service Indicator or provide a signed letter of authorization and the third party’s photo ID.

Question: Where can I find the Parchment Replacement Form?
Answer: On the Simon Fraser University website on the Registrar and Information Services / Student Services page (search “Parchment Replacement Form” on sfu.ca).

Question: What is the rush processing option and how long does it take?
Answer:
Rush processing: an additional $50 + $3.50 (PST) per order; must be made in person or by fax (not available for email/mail‑in) and does not include parchment costs or priority delivery.  
How long: guaranteed to be processed within five business days.

Question: How much does rush processing cost and what does that fee cover?

$50 + $3.50 (PST) per order.

Question: Can I request rush processing by email or regular mail?

Question: How will I be notified when my rush order is completed?

Question: What is the difference between rush processing and priority delivery?
Answer:
Rush processing: an extra $50 + $3.50 (PST) fee that expedites SFU’s processing of your parchment (guaranteed within five business days), must be requested in person or by fax, and does not include parchment or priority‑delivery costs nor is it available for email/mail requests.  
Priority delivery: an additional shipping service (CanadaPost Xpresspost™) that expedites transit time and provides a tracking number for an added regional charge, but it does not speed up SFU’s processing time.

Question: How are parchments shipped for priority delivery and what carrier is used?
Answer: Expedited priority delivery using Canada Post Xpresspost™ with tracking

Question: Who is eligible to apply for a Letter of Permission at SFU?
Answer:
- Students pursuing a degree, diploma, or certificate at SFU (students in non‑degree programs are not eligible)
- Have completed a minimum of 9 units at SFU
- Be in good academic standing at the time of application (may need to wait until their third term)

Question: Can students enrolled in non-degree programs apply for a Letter of Permission?
Answer: No — students enrolled in non-degree programs are not eligible to apply.

Question: How many SFU units must I have completed before I can apply for a Letter of Permission?
Answer: 9 units

Question: Do I need to be in good academic standing to apply for a Letter of Permission?
Answer: Yes. You must be in good academic standing when you submit your application (and have completed a minimum of 9 units at SFU).

Question: When is academic standing determined and how might that affect my eligibility?
Answer: Academic standing is determined after all term grades have been received. Because of this, you may need to wait until those grades are posted—often until your third term (after completing the minimum nine units)—before you are eligible to apply for a Letter of Permission, since you must be in good academic standing at the time of application.

Question: Do I need to consult an advisor before submitting a Letter of Permission application?
Answer: Yes. Students must consult an advisor before submitting: if you've declared a program, meet your departmental advisor; if not, consult your faculty advisor.

Question: Which advisor should I consult if I have declared a program?
Answer: Your departmental advisor.

Question: Which advisor should I consult if I have not yet declared a program?
Answer: Your faculty advisor

Question: How do I apply for a Letter of Permission (where and how do I submit the application)?
Answer:
Where: Email your completed Letter of Permission application and supporting documentation to urecords@sfu.ca.

How: Consult your departmental (if declared) or faculty advisor first; attach the completed application form, supporting documents, and any formal letter request/details required by the other institution; a non‑refundable $40 fee will be charged to your student account upon submission; allow 6–8 weeks for processing.

Question: What supporting documentation must be submitted with the Letter of Permission application?
Answer:
- The completed Letter of Permission application form and any supporting documentation emailed to urecords@sfu.ca.  
- If the other institution requires a formal letter, include your formal letter request with the requesting department’s name and any relevant websites or email addresses outlining their requirements.

Question: Is there an application fee for a Letter of Permission and how much is it?
Answer: Yes. A non-refundable $40 application fee.

Question: How and when is the non-refundable application fee charged to my student account?
Answer: The $40 non‑refundable fee is charged to your student account once you submit the completed Letter of Permission application form and supporting documentation via email to urecords@sfu.ca. The application will be processed once the payment is received.

Question: Is the Letter of Permission application fee refundable if my application is denied?
Answer: No. The application fee is non-refundable.

Question: How long does it take for a Letter of Permission application to be processed?
Answer: Six to eight weeks.

Question: Can a Letter of Permission be approved retroactively?
Answer: No — a Letter of Permission cannot be approved retroactively; you must apply and obtain approval in advance.

Question: If my Letter of Permission application is approved, how long is the approval valid?
Answer: One year from the date of approval.

Question: Will recommendations or approvals from my department or faculty guarantee my Letter of Permission will be granted?
Answer: No. Recommendations and approvals from your department or faculty do not guarantee that your Letter of Permission application will be granted.

Question: For what reasons might a Letter of Permission application be denied?
Answer:
No valid academic reason provided
Enrolled in a non‑degree program (ineligible)
Fewer than 9 units completed at SFU
Not in good academic standing at time of application
Requesting retroactive approval
Course is graded Pass/Fail (does not qualify for transfer credit)
Attempting to remove an F, N, or poor SFU grade by retaking the course elsewhere

Question: Can I use a Letter of Permission to remove an F, N, or poor grade from my SFU record by retaking the course elsewhere?
Answer: No. A student cannot remove an F, N, or poor grade from their SFU record by retaking the course at another institution.

Question: Will transfer credits from a Letter of Permission be included in my SFU CGPA?
Answer: No. Transfer credits are not considered in the calculation of the SFU CGPA.

Question: What grade do I need in courses taken at another institution to receive transfer credit?
Answer: At least a C (2.0) or 60%. Courses graded Pass/Fail (P/F) do not qualify.

Question: Do courses graded Pass/Fail at the other institution qualify for transfer credit?
Answer: No. Courses graded Pass/Fail do not qualify for transfer credit.

Question: Who is responsible for ensuring an official transcript from the visiting institution is sent to SFU?
Answer: The student.

Question: What should I include in a formal letter request if the other institution requires a formal letter from SFU?
Answer:
- Your formal letter request text  
- Name of the requesting department at the other institution  
- Any websites or email addresses that outline the letter requirements

Question: If my Letter of Permission application is not applicable or is denied, how can I request a custom letter and could a fee apply?
Answer:
Contact urecords@sfu.ca to request or discuss a custom letter.  
Yes — a custom letter fee may apply.

Question: How do I log in to goSFU?

Question: How do I enrol in classes through goSFU?
Answer:
1. Log in to goSFU with your SFU Computing ID and password.  
2. Open the Student Centre.  
3. Select the term you want to enrol in.  
4. Go to “Enrolment” → “Manage Classes” (or “Enrol”) in the Student Centre.  
5. Search for courses by subject, course number, or use the class search/timetable tool to find sections.  
6. Add desired sections to your Enrolment Cart or choose “Enrol” directly.  
7. Resolve holds, unmet prerequisites, or obtain permission numbers if required.  
8. Enrol during your assigned enrolment appointment or when registration opens by confirming and submitting the enrolment.  
9. Check your enrolment status/timetable to confirm you’re registered or waitlisted; accept waitlist offers when available.  
10. Pay tuition/fees by the deadline to secure your enrolment; use “Swap” to change sections without losing your spot and drop classes before deadlines if needed.

Question: When and how can I enrol in classes?
Answer:
When: Check SFU’s important dates and deadlines — term-specific enrolment and course-change periods (and your enrolment appointment time) are posted on the Dates & Deadlines page, the Academic Calendar, and in your Student Centre.

How: Enrol online via goSFU (Student Centre) — log in to goSFU, search/select courses and add them during your enrolment appointment; use the Student Centre for course info, schedules, grades and graduation steps.

Student Centre

Question: How can I track my degree progress using the Academic Progress Report (APR)?
Answer:

Question: How can I see what degree requirements I’ve completed?

Question: How do I explore how my courses might transfer to another program?

Question: How do I order transcripts and other official records?

Question: How do I apply to graduate and complete my graduation check?
Answer:

- Complete your graduation check: use the Academic Progress Report (APR) in goSFU to track degree requirements, verify completed/remaining courses, complete the graduation check, then confirm your Convocation attendance.

Question: How do I confirm my attendance at Convocation?
Answer: Complete your graduation check and apply to graduate in your Student Centre (goSFU), then confirm your Convocation attendance through the Convocation/Graduation section on the SFU website or Student Centre.

Question: How can I request a confirmation of enrolment letter or other official documentation?

Question: How do I update my name on my SFU ID card?

Question: What is the mandatory U-Pass BC Program for SFU students?
Answer: A mandatory program that provides SFU students with unlimited access to public transit in Metro Vancouver using a Compass Card.

Question: How do I check my eligibility and fees for the U-Pass BC Program?
Answer: Go to SFU's U‑Pass BC webpage to learn about the program and check your eligibility, fees, and FAQs.

Question: How do I use the Compass Card for U-Pass BC?
Answer:
- Make sure your U‑Pass BC is loaded onto an active Compass Card (issued/activated through SFU).
- Tap your Compass Card on the card reader when boarding buses or at SkyTrain/SeaBus fare gates/validators; hold until you see a green light/beep.
- You don’t need to tap off for U‑Pass trips covered by the program.
- Carry your Compass Card while travelling and present it to transit staff or inspectors if asked.
- If your card is lost, stolen, or not working, contact SFU/TransLink to replace the card and transfer your U‑Pass.

- Access your account and related services via goSFU/Student Centre.

Question: How do I request a refund?

Question: How do I check my exam schedule and understand my student responsibilities for exams?

Question: What study spaces are available and how do I find them?
Answer:
Available study spaces: libraries, labs and other student study spaces (including bookable/group study rooms).

How to find them: explore the “available study spaces” information on the SFU website (exam/study spaces page), check related pages linked from Manage Your Studies, and get help online or in person at SFU Burnaby, Surrey or Vancouver campus offices. Use your SFU ID card for access where required.

Question: What is the exam scheduling procedure and what do I do if I experience exam hardship?
Answer:
Exam scheduling procedure: Check your exam schedule in your Student Centre, review the official scheduling procedure and your student responsibilities, and use available study spaces as needed.

If you experience exam hardship: Explore the supports and resources available to SFU students and connect with the appropriate team for assistance (see the FAQs/get help resources).

Question: Why are tuition refunds and penalties in place at Simon Fraser University?
Answer: Because space in courses is limited and refunds/penalties are intended to discourage students from holding space in courses they ultimately do not use.

Question: What happens if I drop a course after the prescribed refund period?
Answer: You will not be granted a tuition refund if you drop after the prescribed refund period. Special fees are non‑refundable (except the graduation fee and award of certificate/diploma fee). You may apply for an appeal via the Tuition Refund Request page.

Question: How does the policy discourage a student from holding space in courses they do not use?

- Special fees are non‑refundable (except graduation and award of certificate/diploma fees).

What is a T4A and what does it report?
Answer:
A T4A is an official document for tax purposes.  
It reports the amount of scholarships, bursaries, awards, prizes (and other monetary/fellowship payments) a student received from January to December of the tax year.

Question: When will the T4A tax form for 2024 be available for download on goSFU?
Answer:
Please call the helpline at 778.782.6930 or email student_accounts@sfu.ca. If you were also an SFU employee during the year, contact payroll@sfu.ca as Payroll issues employee T4As.

No. Please log into your goSFU to print your T4A under the Finance section.

No. Log into goSFU to print your T4A and distribute it accordingly.

SFU is required to report this information to all students to enable them to complete their Canadian income tax returns. As a resident of Canada you are required to file a Canadian income tax return; your employer issues a T4 for salaries or wages and the university issues a T4A for scholarships, bursaries or other monetary awards received during the calendar year.

Students and Income Tax: www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/forms-publications/publications/p105.html
International Students in Canada: www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/tax/international-non-residents/individuals-leaving-entering-canada-non-residents/international-students-studying-canada.html

T4A slips are issued through goSFU and myINFO. If you received eligible scholarship payments via payroll, a T4A slip would be issued and retrievable via myINFO. Questions about a Payroll‑issued T4A can be directed to Payroll Services at payroll@sfu.ca.

T4A slips are generated for scholarships, fellowships, or bursaries received during the tax year (January to December). If you did not receive such benefits during the year, you will not be issued a T4A slip.  
T2202 slips are tuition tax receipts issued to students who paid tuition for courses in the previous calendar year; they show the amount of tuition paid.

All graduate students are considered full‑time students, regardless of the number of units taken.

For a name change: submit a change of name application to Records via goSFU (see www.sfu.ca/students/forms.html) so the change can be verified and processed.  
For a SIN update: log in to goSFU and update your SIN under the “Personal Information” section.  
Once your personal information is updated in goSFU, email student_accounts@sfu.ca to request an amendment to your T2202 or T4A. Include your student ID, a brief description of the change, and the tax year for the amendment.

Question: Why did I receive T4A and/or T2202 slips issued by SFU?
Answer:
- The T4A reports scholarships, bursaries, awards and prizes received January–December and is an official tax document.  
- The T4A for 2024 will be available to download/print at goSFU on February 28, 2025 (late February each year).  
- SFU will not email T4As — log into goSFU (Finance section) to print. (Not accessible on mobile devices.)  
- If you can’t log in, SFU computing IDs do not expire; reset your password using your SFU computing ID (email) and SFU ID (9‑digit number) or call the IT Service Desk at 778‑782‑8888.  
- For T4A inquiries call 778‑782‑6930 or email student_accounts@sfu.ca. If you were also an SFU employee, contact payroll@sfu.ca for employee-issued T4As.  
- If you receive an error when printing, email a screenshot to student_accounts@sfu.ca.  
- To update name or SIN for a T4A/T2202: update Records or Personal Information in goSFU, then email student_accounts@sfu.ca with your student ID, description of change, and tax year to request an amendment.  
- For CRA guidance on filing taxes as a student or international student, see the CRA pages referenced in goSFU (P105 and International Students pages).

If you receive an error message, please email a screenshot of the message to student_accounts@sfu.ca.

If none of those solutions has worked, contact us at student_accounts@sfu.ca.

Question: Can a student on academic probation enroll in a course overload?
Answer: No.

Question: Who must grant permission for course overloads in the Faculty of Applied Sciences?
Answer:
Approved majors — permission of the director of their school
Other Faculty of Applied Sciences students — permission of the dean of the faculty
(School of Engineering Science and School of Mechatronic Systems Engineering: director’s permission required for overloads exceeding 22 units)

Question: Do students in the School of Engineering Science and the School of Mechatronic Systems Engineering need director permission for overloads exceeding 22 units?
Answer: Yes — permission of the director is required.

Question: Which faculties allow a dean-approved overload to fulfil graduation requirements in the term of enrollment?
Answer: Arts and Social Sciences; Business Administration; Communication, Art and Technology; Education; Environment; Health Sciences

Question: In the Faculty of Science, under what conditions may a student entering the graduating term enroll in courses totalling up to 21 units?
Answer:
- They require specific courses to fulfil graduation requirements in that graduating term.
- Either their cumulative GPA or their most recent term GPA is 3.0 or higher.

Question: Can a dean approve a limited number of overloads on an individual basis during the course change period?
Answer: Yes.

Question: When a student repeats a course, which attempt is recorded as an excluded course on official records?
Answer: The attempt with the lower grade.

Question: If the same grade is earned for a repeated course, which attempt is included in the term GPA and cumulative GPA?
Answer: The most recently completed attempt.

Question: Does a change in GPA from repeating courses alter a student’s academic standing for previous terms?
Answer: No. A student’s academic standing for previous terms does not change even though the GPA changes.

Question: What must a student do if a repeated course has a decreased unit value?
Answer: In consultation with the department, make up the missing unit component before being credited with the full original units.

Question: How are deleted courses treated for the purposes of the repeat course policy?
Answer: When a course is deleted, the department, in consultation with the affected student, will determine a suitable alternative that will be considered a repeat course for the purposes of the policy.

Question: What is the maximum number of courses a student may repeat in a degree program?
Answer: Five

Question: How many times may a student repeat the same course?
Answer: Once.

Question: Do courses completed at SFU for which the student already received transfer credit count toward the five-repeat limit?
Answer: Yes. Courses completed at SFU for which a student has already received transfer credit count toward the five-repeat limit.

Question: Who has priority enrollment when students attempt a course for the first time?
Answer: Students attempting a course for the first time have priority over students presently enrolled in the course or who have passed the course with a C- or better.

Question: Under what conditions can special topics courses be repeated?
Answer: Only if the student previously failed the special topics course and the topic is deemed the same as the one for which they already received credit; otherwise special topics are normally repeatable because the content changes with each offering.

Question: May a student receive transfer credit for a course that is a repeat of a course passed at SFU?
Answer: No. Students may not receive transfer credit for a course that is a repeat of a course passed at Simon Fraser University.

Question: If I enroll in a repeat course and pass it, what happens to the transfer units on my academic record?
Answer: The transfer units remain on your academic record as a repeat with a zero unit value.

Question: If I enroll in a repeat course and fail it, what happens to the transfer units on my academic record?
Answer: The transfer units will remain on the academic record.

Question: Can a department permit units to count for both a transfer course and an SFU course if content differs sufficiently?
Answer: Yes

Question: Do current limits on course repeats apply to repeated transfer courses when one course is an SFU course?
Answer: Yes — current limits on course repeats will apply to repeated transfer courses when one course is an SFU course.

Question: What is the maximum combined number of units obtainable through course challenge and transfer credit?
Answer: 60 units

Question: What eligibility is required to enroll in a course challenge?
Answer: Must be eligible to enroll.

Question: How does the Department of French and the Latin American Studies Program handle challenge enrollment in language sequences?
Answer: With approval, a student may enroll and pay fees to challenge a specified course sequence in a language. If the student satisfactorily completes an advanced-level course, the department may record “successful” for the preceding course(s) in the sequence. If the student does not satisfactorily complete the advanced course, formal challenge assessment of the preceding level(s) should be undertaken to avoid two unsuccessful challenges based solely on the advanced assessment.

Question: How do I enroll as an auditor in a course at SFU?
Answer:
- Meet SFU admission requirements.  
- Obtain written approval from the course instructor and the department chair.  
- Complete the Undergraduate Course Change Application Form with the instructor’s signature and submit it to the department for approval.  
- Application form: www.sfu.ca/students/enrolment-services/forms.  
- Note: Audited courses do not count toward degree requirements (see special audit info at www.sfu.ca/lifelong-learning/special-audit).

Question: What approvals are required to enroll in a course as an auditor?
Answer: Approval from the appropriate instructor and the department chair (written approval of the department).

Question: Where do I obtain the Undergraduate Course Change Application Form for audit enrollment?
Answer: www.sfu.ca/students/enrolment-services/forms

Question: Do audited courses count toward degree program completion?
Answer: No — audited courses do not count toward the completion of degree program requirements.

Question: How are program changes processed and where is the program approval form available?
Answer:
Program changes are processed by the department and require departmental approval.
The program approval application form is available from the appropriate department or on the Student Services website at www.sfu.ca/students/enrolment-services/forms.

Question: Where can I find SFU’s tuition refund policy and important dates and deadlines?
Answer:
www.sfu.ca/students/deadlines
www.sfu.ca/gradstudies/graduate-students/managing-your-program/deadlines

Question: What happens if I stop attending classes but do not formally withdraw from a course?
Answer: Failure to attend does not constitute withdrawal — courses not formally dropped will be given a failing grade, and you remain responsible for the tuition fee.

Question: During the regular term first day through the 7th calendar day, what course changes are allowed and what refund applies?
Answer:
Allowed changes: courses may be added or dropped or tutorial times changed via the enrollment system without prior departmental approval; course challenge/audit changes must be approved by the department (students may change challenge enrollment or switch to regular enrollment).  
Refund: 100% tuition refund for courses dropped on or before the 7th calendar day.

Question: Between the 8th and 14th calendar day after classes begin, what course changes are allowed and what refund is available?
Answer:
Allowed changes: students may drop courses via goSFU; change enrollment in a course challenge to another course or to regular enrollment (department permission required); courses may be added with the permission of the department (no courses can be added or changed to audit status); dropping all term courses will be recorded as a withdrawal.

Refund: 75% refund for courses dropped between the 8th and 14th calendar day.

Question: Between the 15th and 21st calendar day after classes begin, what course changes are allowed and what refund is available?
Answer:
Course changes allowed: Courses may be dropped via goSFU (recorded as WD); courses may be added only with the chair’s and instructor’s permission; no additions or changes to audit status.  
Refund: 50% refund for courses dropped between the 15th and 21st calendar day.

Question: From the 22nd to the 56th calendar day after classes begin, what are the rules for dropping courses and refunds?
Answer:
- Courses may be dropped by the student via goSFU (go.sfu.ca).  
- Courses dropped in this period will be automatically recorded with a WD notation on the academic record.  
- There is no refund for courses dropped after the 21st calendar day.

Question: From the 57th calendar day to the end of term, under what circumstances can courses be dropped and what academic notation is used?
Answer: Only in extenuating circumstances; a WE notation.

Question: What conditions and restrictions apply to WE (withdrawal for extenuating circumstances) applications?
Answer:
- Courses may be dropped for WE only from the 57th calendar day to the last day of the term for extenuating circumstances; if approved, a WE notation is recorded.  
- Applications must be submitted to Student Services.  
- Requests made after the last day of classes or for a previous term are treated as “retroactive,” follow the same procedures, and may take longer to adjudicate.  
- The university has sole discretion to approve WE applications.  
- WE applications are normally denied if the student applies more than once for the same reason, if a retroactive WE is requested more than five years after the date of application, or if there is an academic dishonesty incident report for the course.  
- “Extenuating circumstances” are defined as unusual circumstances beyond the student’s control that make it impossible to complete the course.

Question: How are withdrawals from all courses in a term recorded and where can I find specific term dates?
Answer:
Official records are updated to record the date on which the term withdrawal was effected; the withdrawal date for students who withdraw after the fifth day of classes is recorded on the academic record.
Specific term dates can be found at https://www.sfu.ca/students/deadlines.html.

Question: When are final examinations normally scheduled and where will the exam schedule be posted?
Answer:
During the last two weeks following the last day of classes at the end of each term (Intersession exams in the last week of the session).

On the exams website: https://www.sfu.ca/students/exams.html (exam entries also appear in goSFU and students are emailed when the schedule is released).

Question: What constitutes examination hardship and how are alternative exam dates handled?
Answer:
Examination hardship is when a student is faced with three or more exams (or exams scheduled in conflicting locations/times) during the examination period.  
If hardship occurs, the student will be given a new exam date (within the established exam period) for the second exam causing hardship by the instructor or department/faculty; for exams at more than one location, arrangements will be made so both exams can be written at a single location. Students must notify the instructor(s) and department one month prior to the exam date.

Question: Are in-class final examinations allowed to be held before the official examination period?
Answer: No. In-class final examinations are not to be held before the beginning of the official examination period.

Question: When can take-home examinations be due relative to the official examination period?
Answer: They cannot be due until the commencement of the official examination period.

Question: Within how many hours must instructors submit grades after an exam?
Answer: 96 hours

Question: What situations or circumstances may warrant an academic concession?
Answer: Illness; accident; family situation; similar unanticipated changes in personal responsibilities that create a conflict or warrant particular compassion.

Question: How do I request an academic concession and when is medical documentation required?
Answer:
Complete the Academic Concession Form and speak first with your instructor (departmental approval/policies may also apply).  
Medical documentation is not required for minor/short-term illnesses (expected ≤5 days); instructors may request medical documentation for missed final exams or any assessment worth more than 20% of the final grade, must state documentation requirements in the syllabus, and may ask for additional proof if misuse is suspected.

Question: Where can I find the policy details for Academic Concessions (GP4)?
Answer: See policy GP4 for details.

Question: What guidance does SFU provide for students and instructors in the event of a labour dispute regarding picket lines?
Answer:
- The university respects both the right of unions/members to engage in lawful strike activity and the right of students and instructors to choose whether to cross a legal picket line, and trusts them to understand the consequences of that choice.  
- The guidelines set out responsibilities for students and instructors when they choose to cross or not cross a legal picket line of a union of which they are not a member.  
- Students who do NOT cross a legal picket line and whose course/lab/tutorial proceeds must follow the outlined student responsibilities and, for grading concerns, follow the Grading and Reconsideration of Grades Policy (T 20.01) (instructor first, then chair); see Academic Concessions and Communications sections as needed.  
- Instructors who do NOT cross a legal picket line have specified responsibilities; instructors of record must provide clear, timely communication to students about expectations during a labour dispute.  
- Instructors have a legal duty to accommodate students with disabilities (per SFU Accessibility and Human Rights policies); they should keep the Centre for Accessible Learning (CAL) apprised of course changes that affect accommodated students.  
- Assignment of grades should follow established grading practices as much as possible; if a labour dispute makes that impossible, the university may enact extraordinary measures to ensure course completion.

Question: What responsibilities do students have if they choose not to cross a legal picket line and the course proceeds?
Answer:
- Follow the Grading and Reconsideration of Grades Policy (T 20.01): attempt to resolve grading concerns first with the instructor of record, then with the appropriate chair.
- See the Academic Concessions and Communications with Students sections for related guidance.

Question: What responsibilities do instructors (including instructors of record) have if they do not cross a legal picket line during a labour dispute?
Answer:
- Provide clear, timely communication to students about expectations and course changes during a labour dispute.  
- Consider and administer academic concessions in accordance with policy (students complete the Academic Concession Form; instructors may request documentation for major assessments).  
- Honour legal duties to accommodate students with disabilities and keep the Centre for Accessible Learning (CAL) apprised of course changes.  
- Assign grades following established grading practices as much as possible; if a dispute makes this impossible, work with the chair/dean (or accept university extraordinary measures) to ensure course completion.  
- Where relevant, arrange exam accommodations to minimize hardship (e.g., reschedule a second exam within the exam period for students with three or more exams; consolidate exam locations).

Question: How should grades be assigned if a labour dispute renders established grading practices impossible?
Answer: Grades should follow established grading practices as much as possible; if that is impossible, the university may enact extraordinary measures (via the chair, dean or designate) to ensure students can complete their courses.

Question: Who is responsible for completing a Criminal Record Check (CRC) for programs involving work with children or vulnerable adults?
Answer: All students (and the parent/guardian for students under 19) who work with or have unsupervised access to children and/or vulnerable adults during their program.

Question: Where can I find information about specific courses that require a CRC and the clearance process?
Answer: https://www.sfu.ca/students/enrolment-services/records/criminal-record-check.html

Question: Does SFU require a preadmission medical examination?
Answer: No. SFU does not require a preadmission medical examination, but reserves the right to request a medical certificate at any time.

Question: What medical and hospital insurance coverage are SFU students required to have?
Answer: Adequate hospital and medical insurance: coverage under the BC Medical Services Plan (MSP) or another government or private plan providing equivalent coverage.

Question: Are students responsible for costs not covered by their personal insurance plans?
Answer: Yes — the university is not responsible for any costs not covered by the student’s personal insurance plan.

Question: Must all residents of British Columbia enroll with MSP and how long can dependent MSP coverage continue for students?
Answer:
Yes.  
Dependent coverage continues until the student’s 19th birthday and may be extended up to the 25th birthday if the student is full‑time and mainly dependent on their parents (must notify MSP each September).

Question: What should Canadian students who are not BC residents do about medical coverage while attending SFU?
Answer: Maintain coverage in their home province; their province will cover physician visits and hospital costs while attending SFU provided any required hospital insurance premiums have been paid.

Question: How are new international, exchange, and study abroad students insured during their first term at SFU?
Answer: They are automatically enrolled in a mandatory four‑month primary medical insurance plan through guard.me@SFU for their first term, providing interim coverage during the BC MSP waiting period; they may opt out if they have BC MSP or an eligible plan.

Question: Can international students opt out of the mandatory guard.me@SFU four-month primary insurance and under what conditions?
Answer: Yes — they may opt out if they already have coverage under the BC Medical Services Plan (BC MSP) or coverage under an eligible alternative insurance plan.

Question: Do I have to have medical insurance for the entire duration of my studies?
Answer: Yes — you must have medical insurance for the entire duration of your studies.

Question: What happens if I am not insured in the Canadian health system?
Answer: Care is very expensive if you are not insured. You could pay thousands of dollars per day for a hospital stay. You could even be refused certain services.

Answer: Yes — without insurance you could pay thousands of dollars per day for a hospital stay.

- Letter of Permission application fee ($40) — non‑refundable

- Completion of external forms fee ($20 + PST) — non‑refundable

Question: What are the consequences of having an overdue account at SFU?
Answer:
- Considered in bad financial standing and precluded from enrolling in subsequent terms  
- Withholding of services/documents (e.g., official transcripts, letters, parchments for degrees/diplomas/certificates)  
- Account may be forwarded to a collection agency  
- Returned-cheque penalty of $30; repeated dishonours may require certified cheque or money order for future payments  
- University may cancel a student’s enrollment in a term when payments are dishonoured  
- Monthly interest charge of 2% on the outstanding balance (regardless of pending scholarships, bursaries, awards, waivers)

Question: How do students apply for government student financial assistance?
Answer:
- Apply with your province or territory of residence.  
- Submit an application to your provincial/territorial student financial assistance program (you will be automatically considered for all eligible loans and grants).  
- Complete and sign the Master Student Financial Assistance Agreement (MSFAA) through the National Student Loans Service Centre (NSLSC) using your personal bank account details.  
- Use NSLSC Online Services via a My Service Canada Account (MCSA) to review/manage your MSFAA and loans (required as of May 1, 2025).

Question: Must students apply with the province or territory in which they plan to study?
Answer: No — students apply with their province or territory of residence, not necessarily where they plan to study.

Question: What will Financial Aid and Awards do if a student has outstanding tuition and fees and uses their own bank account details?
Answer: Automatically deduct the outstanding amount and redirect it to your SFU student account.

Question: What happens if a student provides SFU’s banking information when completing the MSFAA?
Answer: SFU will deduct outstanding tuition and fees and deposit any remaining funds into its general bank account, causing delays because SFU cannot match the funds to your student account and will return them to the NSLSC to be re‑matched.

Question: Will the MSFAA show the amounts of loans and grants a student will receive?
Answer: No. The MSFAA will not show loan and grant amounts; you’ll receive a Notice of Assessment from your province or territory showing how much you’ll get.

Question: How will students find out how much student assistance they will receive per application?
Answer: They will receive a Notice of Assessment from their province or territory showing how much assistance they will receive per application.

Question: Do you accept cryptocurrency payments?
Answer: No. Simon Fraser University does not accept cryptocurrency payments and is not responsible for any fees related to such payments. Please use accepted methods (e.g., Visa/MasterCard, Flywire, internet banking, or in-person Canadian debit/personal cheques).

Question: Who is responsible for any fees related to cryptocurrency payments?
Answer:
We do not accept cryptocurrency payments; SFU is not responsible for any related fees.

U-Pass BC term fee is added to your student financial account the next business day after enrolment.

Payments made on the tuition deadline date will not incur the 2% monthly interest charge if proof of payment date can be provided.

Internet banking payments may take 2–3 business days to appear on your SFU account.

In-person payments at Registrar and Information Services (RIS) counters are reflected immediately; accepted at counters: Canadian bank debit cards and Canadian personal cheques. Digital wallets (Google Pay, Apple Pay, AliPay) are not accepted at the counter.

Flywire is available on goSFU for domestic and international payments; processing time depends on the Flywire payment method chosen.

Flywire Payment Plans are available for installments; meeting Flywire’s installment requirements keeps your account in good standing for the next term, but payment plans do not exempt you from the 2% monthly interest on unpaid balances beyond the tuition deadline.

Check your current outstanding balance on goSFU: Student Centre → Account Inquiry (Finances) → Activity tab.

Tuition fees are due at the end of Week 2 each term (see Fees: payment and refunds for exact dates).

If your account still shows a charge after payment, it may be due to processing delays (e.g., Flywire or internet banking); processing times vary by method.

For payment options and instructions, see How to make a payment; SFU recommends electronic payment via your Canadian bank’s website for speed and security. goSFU accepts Visa and MasterCard online.

To pay from outside Canada on goSFU, use Flywire (see Payments with Flywire for instructions).

Supplementary fees are assessed for all eligible students; if they appear on your account you meet the eligibility criteria.

U-Pass BC is mandatory for members of the SFSS and GSS; exemptions may be considered under specific criteria listed on the U-Pass BC eligibility website and must be applied for before the exemption deadline.

Student Services and Student Activity fees are charged for remote courses because those services and student societies continue to provide support and programming remotely and in person.

Application fees: Visa and MasterCard are the only accepted forms of payment (prepaid/gift credit cards may be used if you don’t have a credit card).

Undergraduate admission deposit: paid on goSFU with Visa/MasterCard; amounts are $250 for Canadian students and $5,000 for international students. Graduate deposit amounts and payment methods vary by program; pay via the graduate online application system or other listed methods.

If you have overpaid, submit a refund request form to Student Accounts (see refunds section).

- Application fees: Visa or MasterCard only (prepaid/gift cards accepted).
- Undergraduate admission deposit: Visa/MasterCard ($250 Canadian students; $5,000 international). Graduate deposit/payment methods may vary by program.

Other key points:
- Flywire Payment Plans available; meeting Flywire’s installment terms keeps your account in good standing for next-term enrolment, but monthly interest still applies to unpaid balances.
- Payments made on the tuition deadline date won’t incur the 2% monthly interest charge if proof of payment date can be provided.
- U-Pass BC is mandatory for SFSS and GSS members; exemptions may be granted if you apply before the deadline.
- Residence/housing fees have separate payment options.
