Question: What should I do if I am having difficulty with my SFU courses?
Answer:
- Make an appointment with an academic advisor as soon as possible.  
- If you’re on Academic Probation, work with an advisor to develop a plan to return to Good Academic Standing.  
- Talk to your instructor about your progress and possible options (e.g., deferrals, extensions).  
- Use tutoring and academic supports (Student Learning Commons, study-skill workshops).  
- Check withdrawal deadlines and consider a Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances if appropriate.  
- Meet with a Financial Aid Advisor if withdrawing to discuss impacts on loans/scholarships.  
- Review the Guide to Academic Standing and Continuance and consider programs like Back on Track if required.

Question: Do I need to make an appointment with an academic advisor if I am on Academic Probation?
Answer: Yes. If you are on Academic Probation you should make an appointment with an academic advisor as soon as possible to help you work toward Good Academic Standing.

Question: What is Academic Probation (OAP) and how does it work?
Answer:
What is Academic Probation (OAP)?
- You are placed on Academic Probation if you have attempted at least 9 units and your cumulative GPA (CGPA) is below 2.00.  
- It indicates you are not in Good Academic Standing; sustained marginal passes (C- or D) can lead to OAP.  
- While on OAP you may be ineligible for a Letter of Permission (LOP).

How does it work?
- Academic standing is evaluated at the end of each term once you have attempted nine or more units.  
- To get off probation you must achieve both a Term GPA and a CGPA of 2.00 or higher at the next evaluation.  
- If, while on OAP, your Term GPA is below 2.00 AND your CGPA is below 2.00, you will be Required to Withdraw (RTW).  
- You may be placed on Continued Academic Probation (CAP) until you attain a Term GPA ≥ 2.00; during CAP you may repeat failed courses.  
- You should meet with an academic advisor as soon as possible for planning and support.

Question: When is my academic standing first evaluated at SFU?
Answer: After you have attempted nine units — your record is first evaluated at the end of that term (and then at the end of each subsequent term).

Question: How many units must I attempt before my record is evaluated for academic standing?
Answer: 9 units

Question: What CGPA threshold places a student on Academic Probation?
Answer: Below 2.00

Question: Can passing all my courses still result in Academic Probation?
Answer: Yes — if after attempting at least 9 units your cumulative GPA is below 2.00 you will be placed on Academic Probation, even if you passed all courses (e.g., with marginal C-/D grades).

Question: How does sustained performance at the marginal pass level affect my CGPA?
Answer: Even if you pass every course, sustained performance at the marginal pass level (C- or D) will lower your CGPA below 2.00 and result in being placed on Academic Probation (OAP).

Question: Can students on Academic Probation get a Letter of Permission (LOP) to take courses elsewhere?
Answer: No. Students on Academic Probation may not be approved for a Letter of Permission (LOP) to take courses at another institution.

Question: How do I get off Academic Probation and return to Good Academic Standing (GAS)?
Answer:
- Raise both your Term GPA and your Cumulative GPA to 2.00 or higher (your standing is re‑evaluated at the end of the next completed term).  
- Book an appointment with an academic advisor immediately to develop a plan to get off probation.  
- Repeat failed courses if eligible to improve your CGPA (follow repeat limits and department permission rules).  
- Use supports: tutoring, Student Learning Commons workshops, study‑skill resources, and referrals from advisors.  
- If applicable, consider the Back on Track program (three‑term supported program) or apply for a Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances if appropriate.

Question: When will my Academic Standing be re-evaluated after being placed on probation?
Answer: At the end of the next completed term.

Question: What Term and Cumulative GPA do I need to achieve to get back into Good Academic Standing?
Answer:
Term GPA: 2.00 or higher
Cumulative GPA: 2.00 or higher

Question: Where can I download the Guide to Academic Standing and Continuance?
Answer: From the SFU website — the "Academic Standing and Continuance" section (click "Download Guide to Academic Standing and Continuance").

Question: How many times can a student be on Continued Academic Probation (CAP)?
Answer: You may be on CAP for as long as it takes to attain a Term GPA of 2.00 or higher (no set limit).

Question: Can students on CAP repeat failed courses?
Answer: Yes — students on Continued Academic Probation (CAP) may repeat courses they have failed.

Question: Can I graduate while remaining on Academic Probation?
Answer: No. To graduate you must have a cumulative GPA (CGPA) of 2.00 or higher — you cannot graduate while your CGPA remains below 2.00 (i.e., while on Academic Probation).

Question: Where can I get help with course planning and improving my academic standing?
Answer:
Academic advisors in Student Services
See the Contact Us page to book an appointment with an academic advisor

Question: How do I book an appointment with an academic advisor at SFU?
Answer: Visit the Student Services "Contact Us" page on the SFU website for information on how to book an appointment with an academic advisor.

Question: What does Required to Withdraw (RTW) mean and when is it applied?
Answer:
Required to Withdraw (RTW) means you must leave SFU, may not enroll in classes (existing enrolment for the next term will be cancelled) and any fees paid will be refunded upon application.

RTW is applied when, while on Academic Probation (OAP), your Term GPA is below 2.00 AND your Cumulative GPA (CGPA) is also below 2.00.

Question: What happens to my enrolment and fees if I am RTW and already enrolled for the next term?
Answer: Your enrolment will be cancelled, and any fees paid for that term will be refunded upon application for a tuition refund.

Question: How can I get back into SFU after being Required to Withdraw?
Answer:
1) Apply for readmission: consult the BC Transfer Guide to find equivalent courses, then apply for readmission online via EducationPlanner BC by the admissions deadlines (check Admissions for deadline updates).

2) Enter the Back on Track Program: a three-term program with guided analysis, personalized academic advice/support and career advising to help you return to good standing.

Question: What is Option 1 for returning to SFU after RTW?
Answer:
Consult the BC Transfer Guide to determine if a course is equivalent to one you've taken at SFU or before entering SFU.

Apply for readmission by the deadlines listed on the admissions website via the EducationPlanner BC online application.

Question: How do I apply for readmission to SFU after RTW?
Answer:
- Option 1: Complete coursework at another post‑secondary institution (use the BC Transfer Guide to check equivalencies/required grades), then apply for readmission online through EducationPlannerBC by the admission deadlines (check Admissions for updates).

- Option 2: If eligible (first‑time RTW), enter the Back on Track Student Success Program — a three‑term program with academic supports and concurrent credit courses — to regain standing.

Question: What is the Back on Track Program and how can it help students who are RTW?
Answer:
What is the Back on Track Program?
A three-term student success program (for first-time RTW students) that provides guided analysis of academic difficulties, personalized academic advice and support, career advising, and structured learning-skill development, with concurrent credit course enrollment in Terms 2 and 3.

How can it help students who are RTW?
By addressing the factors behind poor performance, teaching study and learning skills, offering personalized academic and career guidance, allowing supported reenrollment in credit courses, and improving students’ chances of returning to Good Academic Standing and completing their degree.

Question: How long is the Back on Track Program and what does it involve?
Answer:
Three terms.

Guided analysis of areas of difficulty, personalized academic advice and support, career advising, academic and learning-skills development, and concurrent credit course enrollment in Terms Two and Three.

Question: How can students on Extended Withdrawal (PW) become eligible for readmission to SFU?
Answer: By completing one of five specified options at another post‑secondary institution.

Question: What is a Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances (WE) and when might I apply for it?
Answer:
A Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances (WE) is a withdrawal granted after the regular course‑drop deadline for students who experienced unusual circumstances beyond their control; if approved, a WE notation appears on the transcript (approval is not guaranteed).

You would apply for a WE if you have passed the deadline to drop courses on your own and events beyond your control made it impossible for you to complete the course.

Question: If I miss the deadline to drop courses, when might a WE notation appear on my transcript?
Answer: If your application for a Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances (WE) is approved after you’ve passed the drop deadline.

Question: What alternatives should I consider before dropping a class?
Answer:
- Talk to your instructor (get feedback, possible deferrals or extensions)  
- Tutoring and other supports (study skills classes, workshops, Student Learning Commons)  
- Check withdrawal deadlines  
- Consider financial implications (consult a Financial Aid Advisor)  
- Apply for a Withdrawal Under Extenuating Circumstances (WE) if you missed the deadline

Question: Should I speak to my instructor before dropping a course?
Answer: Yes — talk to your instructor. You don’t need their approval to drop the course, but they can tell you how you’re doing, suggest improvements, and explain other options (e.g., deferrals, extensions).

Question: What tutoring and support resources are available to help me avoid dropping a course?
Answer:
- Talk to your instructor (office hours) for feedback and options (deferrals, extensions).  
- Tutoring through the Student Learning Commons.  
- Study-skill classes and workshops (Student Learning Commons / campus workshops).  
- Academic advisors in Student Services for course planning and referrals to supports.  
- Financial Aid Advisor (if withdrawing would affect loans/scholarships).

Question: How can withdrawing from a class affect my financial assistance?
Answer:
- Withdrawing can impact your current or future financial assistance (may affect eligibility or amounts).  
- If you have a student loan or a scholarship/bursary, meet with a Financial Aid Advisor to notify them and get guidance.  
- See SFU Financial Aid (www.sfu.ca/students/financialaid/) for more information.

Question: Where can I get advice about the financial implications of withdrawing from courses?
Answer: Meet with a Financial Aid Advisor — www.sfu.ca/students/financialaid/

Question: What are the limits on repeating courses in a degree program at SFU?
Answer:
- You may not repeat more than five courses in a degree program (courses with prior transfer credit count toward this limit).  
- This limit may be extended by the dean of the faculty.  
- No individual course may be repeated more than once except with permission of the department; enrolling a course for a third time requires departmental permission.

Question: Can I repeat an individual course more than once?
Answer: No — you may not repeat an individual course more than once except with permission of the department; students wishing to enroll a third time should consult the department.

Question: How are repeated transfer credits treated on my SFU academic record?
Answer:
- You may not receive transfer credit for a course that is a repeat of a course you already passed at SFU.  
- If you take a repeat at another institution and pass, the transfer credit will remain on your SFU record as a repeat with zero unit value.  
- If you fail the repeat elsewhere or drop it, the transfer credit will still remain on your record.  
- A department may allow credit to count for both the transfer course and an SFU course if the content is judged sufficiently different.  
- Current limits on course repeats (including the five-course repeat limit) apply to repeated transfer courses, and this policy does not change how GPAs are calculated.

Question: Who should I consult if I want to enroll in a sixth or subsequent repeat of a course?
Answer:
Your major department advisor
Academic Advising

Question: What do I need to complete in order to graduate from my degree program?

- WQB requirements (Writing, Quantitative, and Breadth)

Question: Do I have to choose or declare a major in my first year?
Answer: You are not required to choose or declare a major in your first year, but it is a good time to try different courses to narrow your choices. We recommend first‑year students use their WQB requirements to study interests outside their major, as these units will still count toward their degree.

Question: When is a good time to try different courses to narrow my major choices?
Answer: Your first year.

Question: Can WQB requirement courses count toward my degree if taken in first year?
Answer: Yes — WQB courses taken in first year will count toward your degree. They can be used to explore interests outside your major and will apply to W/Q/B requirements if completed with a C- or better.

Question: How do I use the My Planner tool to plan courses and enrol?

FAN = Foundations of Analytical and Quantitative Reasoning — prerequisite for Q (Quantitative) courses.

Question: What is the purpose of the GPA Calculator?

Question: What calculator modes can I select?

Question: What does the "C/GPA calculator" mode do?
Answer: Calculates your cumulative (and term) GPA from the courses you enter by using their grades and units.

Question: What does "GPA for target CGPA" mode do?
Answer: Calculates the GPA you must earn in upcoming course(s)/term (based on your current CGPA, total units, and planned units) to reach a desired cumulative GPA.

Question: What does "Units for target CGPA" mode do?
Answer: Calculates how many additional units you must complete (based on your current CGPA/units and an assumed future GPA) to reach a desired cumulative GPA.

Question: How do I add or remove a course in the calculator?

Click the "‑ Remove Course" button to remove a course.

Question: What buttons are available to calculate or reset values in the calculator?

Calculate C/GPA
Reset
Calculate required GPA
Calculate required units

Question: How do I calculate my cumulative GPA using the tool?
Answer:
1. Select "C/GPA calculator" mode.  
2. Click "+ Add Course" for each course and enter the course units and letter grade.  
3. Make sure total units attempted come from your transcript (download from go.sfu.ca); do not include units in progress.  
4. Click "Calculate C/GPA."  
5. Note: repeats/duplicate courses are not handled—see an Academic Advisor; calculator is for SFU grades/units only.

Question: How do I calculate the GPA required to reach a target CGPA?
Answer:
Let C = current CGPA, Uc = units completed, T = target CGPA, Un = additional units you will take, Greq = required GPA in those units.

Greq = (T*(Uc + Un) - C*Uc) / Un

(If instead you know the GPA you can achieve, Gexp, and want required units Un:)

Un = (T - C) * Uc / (Gexp - T)

Question: How do I calculate the number of units required to reach a target CGPA?
Answer:
Let U = current units, C = current CGPA, T = target CGPA, g = expected GPA in future units, n = additional units required.

n = U*(T - C)/(g - T)

If T ≤ C then n = 0. If g ≤ T then impossible.

Using maximum possible grade M: n = U*(T - C)/(M - T)

Question: What is an academic concession?
Answer: An academic concession is granted when unexpected situations or circumstances prevent a student from participating in course-related activities (e.g., missing a class or completing graded work or exams). Examples include illness, accident, family situations, or other unanticipated changes in personal responsibilities that create a conflict or warrant compassion.

1. Read the Co‑op Student Guide and FAQs; determine if co‑op is optional or mandatory for your degree; if international, check co‑op work permit and requirements; know faculty GPA requirements; consider unconventional co‑op options and ask co‑op staff.

2. Attend virtual or in‑person co‑op info sessions; check the co‑op info session schedule; view the Co‑op Office Directory; book or drop in to meet with a co‑op advisor.

3. Best time to join: second term of first year (~24–30 units). If ~45–60 units, join soon. If >70–80 units, apply ASAP and discuss a Work/Study plan. If >90 units, it’s often too late—contact staff. Mandatory co‑op students are auto‑enrolled. Review the refund policy. Staff will contact you within 10 business days about Conditional Approval.

4. After acceptance: remain in classes and register in the prerequisite Canvas course; complete resume, cover letter, and interview workshops; gain access to co‑op job postings, apply and interview; take a 4‑ or 8‑month work term (tuition still applies); a mid‑term site visit will be arranged. Students typically have ~45–60 credit hours at the start of their first work term.

5. Unconventional options include international co‑op, engineering research co‑op (ENG/SEE/MSE), Beedie CPA‑counted work terms, SFSS executive roles as co‑op, Entrepreneurship Co‑op (eCoop), student‑developed work terms, NCAA‑friendly pathways, and co‑op for certain post‑undergraduate programs. Contact relevant co‑op staff to pursue these.

Question: What is Co-operative Education (co-op)?
Answer: Co-operative Education (co-op) is an educational model that formally integrates academic study with paid employment, where students alternate periods of classroom learning with degree‑relevant work experience.

Question: How does the standard co-op program structure academic study and work experience?
Answer: It formally integrates academic experience with paid employment by alternating academic study with work experience in degree-relevant fields.

Question: Who accredits SFU’s co-op programs?
Answer: Co-operative Education and Work-Integrated Learning (CEWIL) Canada

Question: What does CEWIL Canada accreditation confirm about the co-op program?
Answer: That the program meets national standards for quality in Co-operative Education and is a recognized educational strategy that effectively integrates work experiences with the academic curriculum, enhancing student learning and encouraging reflection.

Question: How does co-op integrate work experiences with the academic curriculum?
Answer:
- By formally alternating academic study with paid employment in degree-relevant fields.  
- By integrating workplace experience with coursework so students apply classroom knowledge, enhance learning and reflect on their careers.  
- Through CEWIL Canada accreditation, which confirms the program meets national standards for integrating work experiences with the curriculum.

Question: Where can I find the co-op roadmap to help decide how co-op fits my post-secondary experience?
Answer: On SFU’s Co‑op program webpage — review our roadmap (linked on the Co‑op Programs page).

Question: How can I contact my co-op program office or a co-op advisor?

Office address: 8888 University Drive, Burnaby, B.C., Canada V5A 1S6.

Question: Are co-op staff available in person, virtually, or both?
Answer: Both in-person and virtually.

Question: What application fees, tuition, deadlines, and program-specific requirements should I be aware of?
Answer:
- Application fees: check your specific Co‑op program office for current application fee amounts.  
- Tuition: be aware of regular tuition and any Co‑op‑specific fees—confirm exact amounts with your Co‑op program office.  
- Deadlines: follow program‑specific application deadlines and termly application windows (Co‑op info sessions are offered in the first month of every term); check your program office for exact dates.  
- Program‑specific requirements: degree‑relevant work eligibility, submission of resume and cover letter, interview requirements, any eligibility/academic criteria set by your program, and completion expectations (recommended at least two separate employers, up to three full work terms); confirm all details with your Co‑op program office.

Question: What is the process for applying to co-op and what are the next steps after applying?
Answer:
1) Process for applying to co‑op:
- Review the co‑op roadmap and program-specific requirements (fees, tuition, deadlines).  
- Attend co‑op info sessions and explore program resources.  
- Start your application and contact your co‑op program office or meet with a co‑op advisor (in‑person or virtually) for one‑on‑one support.  
- Use co‑op supports to prepare your resume, cover letter and interview skills.

2) Next steps after applying:
- Follow the program’s timeline and guidance on what to expect while participating.  
- Continue meeting with co‑op staff/advisors for planning and support.  
- Prepare for work‑term placement(s) (interviews, employer matching, onboarding).  
- Complete work terms to gain experience, references and potential full‑time offers; reflect on outcomes to inform your academic/career plans.

Question: What should I expect to happen after applying to the co-op program?
Answer:
- Receive guidance on what happens next and tips for planning your co-op timeline.  
- Be invited to co-op info sessions and encouraged to RSVP/attend.  
- Meet with co-op staff or an advisor (in-person or virtually) for one‑on‑one support.  
- Get help preparing your resume, cover letter, and interview skills.  
- Apply for and be matched with paid, degree‑relevant work terms (employers provide mentorship/training).  
- Build professional relationships, references, and LinkedIn connections; possible full‑time offers.  
- Complete multiple work terms (recommended at least two different employers, up to three terms) to reflect and refine career direction.  
- Use work‑term experiences to smooth the transition between academic study and the workplace.

Question: What tips are available for planning my timeline to get the most from co-op experiences?
Answer:
- Complete work terms with at least two separate employers, aiming for up to three full terms of work experience.  
- Consider taking one or two terms off studies to earn income and apply your degree knowledge.  
- Prepare your resume, cover letter, and interview skills before applying.  
- Know application fees, tuition, deadlines and program-specific requirements and build them into your timeline.  
- Attend Co-op info sessions (offered in the first month of every term) to learn timelines and expectations.  
- Contact your Co-op program office or meet with a Co-op advisor for one-on-one timeline planning and support.  
- Review the Co-op roadmap and guidance on what happens after applying so you can plan next steps.

Question: How does co-op help build professional relationships and industry connections?
Answer:
- Creates professional relationships with real industry contacts during work terms
- Provides potential references
- Builds new LinkedIn and networking connections
- Offers employer mentorship and training
- Can lead to full‑time employment offers upon graduation

Question: What kinds of outcomes might result from co-op work terms (e.g., references, LinkedIn connections, job offers)?
Answer:
- Potential references
- New LinkedIn connections
- Offers for full-time employment upon graduation
- Professional industry connections/relationships
- Mentorship and on-the-job training
- Paid work experience (earned income)
- Improved resume, cover letter, and interview skills
- Experience with multiple employers (career exploration)
- Practical application of classroom knowledge and new perspectives

Question: How does the co-op program support students with resumes, cover letters, and interview skills?
Answer:
- Helps you prepare your resume, cover letter, and interview skills to ensure you put your best foot forward.  
- Provides one-on-one support with co-op advisors, available in-person or virtually.  
- Offers info sessions and staff support to guide application and interview preparation.

Question: Why does SFU recommend students complete work terms with at least two separate employers?
Answer: To allow students to reflect on their career and pivot if necessary by gaining varied experience from different employers and building up to three full terms of work experience.

Question: How many full terms of work experience does SFU suggest students aim for?
Answer: Three

Question: How are co-op opportunities different from internships?
Answer:
- They offer real work experiences with actual compensation.  
- They are a formal educational model integrating academic study with paid employment (academic study alternating with work terms).  
- They allow you to take one or two terms away from studies to earn income and apply degree knowledge.  
- They provide a supportive, co-op-only placement environment with employer mentorship and training.

Question: Are co-op work terms compensated?
Answer: Yes — co-op work terms are compensated.

Question: How can co-op serve as a break from studies while allowing students to earn income?
Answer: By offering paid work terms that let students pause their studies for one or two terms to earn income while applying their degree knowledge in real workplace settings.

Question: In what way does co-op reduce competition for job placements compared to the broader job market?
Answer: Students only compete with other co-op students for job placements rather than with the entire broader job market.

Question: How do employers support students during co-op work terms?
Answer:
Provide mentorship and training to foster learning outcomes during work terms.
Offer paid, real work experience (compensation).
Create professional relationships and provide references and LinkedIn connections.
In some cases, extend offers for full‑time employment upon graduation.

Question: How does co-op help smooth the transition from academic study to the working world?
Answer:
- Allows you to apply classroom knowledge in the workplace  
- Gives new perspectives that contextualize studies when you return to class  
- Provides mentorship and on-the-job training  
- Builds professional industry connections, references, and potential full-time job offers  
- Develops job-search skills (resume, cover letter, interview)

Question: What support is available for students returning to the classroom after a work term?
Answer:
Co-op staff and advisors available in-person or virtually for one‑on‑one support.

Work‑term experience gives new perspectives that contextualize studies and smooth the transition back to the classroom.

Question: How should I get my resume ready for international opportunities?

- Highlight relevant international experience, language skills, and cross-cultural competencies.  
- Tailor your cover letter to explain your motivation, fit for the role, and what you bring internationally.  
- Get feedback from your Co-op Program Coordinator or career services and use SFU’s international co-op resources (readiness checklist, guides).

- Contact information and a polite call to action/closing statement

Question: What does the statistic "Only one in six 25 year olds are pursuing the same job they thought they would do when they were 17" mean for my career planning?
Answer:
- Careers are fluid: expect your path to change and be prepared to adapt.  
- Prioritize transferable skills (communication, problem-solving, learning) over specific job titles.  
- Use your major as a foundation, not a box that limits possibilities.  
- Stay curious and explore multiple options through internships, volunteering, and side projects.  
- Treat career planning as iterative—try things, reflect, and adjust course regularly.  
- Build a network and conduct informational interviews to discover real-world roles and pathways.  
- Embrace small risks and experiments to gain clarity and practical experience.  
- Invest in continuous learning to keep up with changing industries and technologies.  
- Align choices with evolving values, interests, and strengths rather than fixed long-term plans.  
- Leverage career services and resources to test options and craft a flexible plan.

Question: How can my major open up multiple career possibilities?
Answer:
- Provides transferable skills (critical thinking, communication, research, teamwork, problem-solving)
- Gives foundational knowledge you can apply across industries
- Opens pathways to related roles through industry-specific technical skills
- Enables specialization or pivoting with minors, electives, or certificates
- Serves as preparation for graduate/professional programs (law, business, medicine, etc.)
- Supports interdisciplinary careers by combining your major with other interests
- Builds credibility for roles in research, teaching, policy, or consulting
- Creates opportunities for internships, co-ops, and experiential learning that lead to jobs
- Helps you develop a portfolio or body of work to showcase to employers
- Facilitates networking and informational interviews that reveal new career options
- Encourages entrepreneurial ventures by giving subject-matter expertise
- Strengthens adaptability to changing job markets and emerging fields
- Teaches design-thinking and problem-solving approaches useful in many roles
- Helps you identify values and interests that guide meaningful career choices
- Gives a platform to take small risks and iterate toward satisfying career paths

Question: Why should I avoid letting my major define my identity?
Answer:
- Your major is just one part of your story alongside skills, knowledge, values, and talents.  
- It limits the many career possibilities your degree can open.  
- Career interests and opportunities often change between 17 and 25 (and beyond).  
- Fixed planning assumes a predictable future, but technology, economy, climate, and politics create uncertainty.  
- You will change—your values, interests, abilities, and self‑view evolve over time.  
- Treating your major as identity reduces flexibility, creativity, and openness to new paths.  
- Careers aren’t linear; all situations are temporary and exploration can lead to better fits.  
- Viewing your degree as a foundation lets you build diverse career options rather than be confined by a label.

Question: What other elements besides my major should I include in my career story?
Answer:
- Skills (technical and transferable)
- Knowledge and subject expertise
- Values and motivations
- Talents and strengths
- Interests and passions
- Work experiences (jobs, internships, co-op)
- Volunteer and community involvement
- Projects, research, and portfolio
- Achievements and awards
- Certifications and languages
- Leadership and extracurricular activities
- Networks and informational interviews/connections
- Career goals and desired impact
- Learning mindset and adaptability
- Personal narrative — how you want to be in the world
- Communication skills and personal brand

Question: How might the options I’m considering now change by the time I graduate?
Answer:
- New jobs and fields may emerge (technology, climate, policy changes).  
- Some roles may shrink or change in scope; job tasks may be automated or redefined.  
- Employer demand and hiring patterns may shift with the economy and industry trends.  
- Required skills may change — you may need to learn new technical or soft skills.  
- Your values, interests, and strengths may evolve, steering you toward different paths.  
- Internships, volunteer work, and part‑time roles may reveal unexpected careers.  
- Networking and informational interviews can open opportunities you hadn’t considered.  
- Further study, certificates, or credentials may become attractive or necessary.  
- Geographic or sector mobility may create different options than those available now.  
- You may pursue portfolio or hybrid careers instead of a single linear job.

Question: What does it mean to be curious and open-minded in career exploration?
Answer:
- Asking lots of questions about industries, roles, tasks, and day‑to‑day work instead of assuming you already know the answer
- Exploring a range of possibilities (even those outside your major) and entertaining career paths you hadn’t considered
- Conducting research and curiosity‑driven actions: informational interviews, job shadows, volunteer roles, internships, and attending events
- Trying small experiments and calculated risks to test interests (short projects, micro‑internships, freelance work, course electives)
- Being willing to change direction as you learn more about yourself, the market, and what work feels meaningful
- Looking for clues and patterns in experiences to refine your preferences and priorities
- Applying a learning mindset: treating setbacks and surprises as data, not failures, and iterating on your plans
- Listening to others’ stories and feedback with an open mind to expand how you imagine possible futures
- Focusing on transferable skills and how different roles could use your strengths rather than fixating on job titles
- Balancing curiosity with gradual commitment: make small decisions that create momentum while staying adaptable

Question: How can I identify clues to help me make confident career decisions?
Answer:
- Be curious and open-minded; notice what genuinely interests you and how your interests change over time
- Reflect on your values, skills, talents, and what kinds of challenges you want to tackle
- Ask targeted questions: how far and wide will my degree take me? where and how can I contribute?
- Use design‑thinking: reframe the career question as a problem to prototype and iterate on
- Conduct informational interviews and talk with people in roles/fields of interest
- Network and build connections; watch for opportunities and insider insights
- Take small risks: try short projects, internships, volunteer roles, or contract work to test options
- Run thought experiments and mini‑projects to surface preferences and strengths
- Research industries, employers, and labour‑market trends (technology, economy, climate, policy)
- Learn to talk about your story and skills confidently; notice which narratives resonate with others
- Jump into current job opportunities to see who’s hiring and what roles look like in practice
- Use career services, mentors, and feedback loops to interpret clues and refine decisions

Question: How far and wide can my degree take me?
Answer:
- Very far and wide: your degree opens multiple career possibilities across industries, roles, and locations.  
- Transferable skills matter: employers value the skills, knowledge, values and talents you developed, not just the major title.  
- Your major shouldn’t define you: combine it with your interests, strengths and values to create varied pathways.  
- Careers aren’t linear: many people change direction; only one in six 25‑year‑olds work in the job they imagined at 17.  
- The future is uncertain: tech, economy, climate and society shape opportunities, so flexibility is key.  
- You shape the outcome: what you want to do and the work that needs doing together determine possibilities.  
- Take action and small risks: experimenting, networking and information interviews reveal real options.  
- Use resources and frameworks: design thinking, career services, research and self‑branding accelerate exploration.  
- Be curious and open‑minded: stay adaptable, learn continuously, and follow emerging clues to new careers.

Question: What kinds of challenges should I consider wanting to tackle in my career?
Answer:
- Solving social inequality and improving access to services  
- Addressing climate change and environmental sustainability  
- Developing and implementing new technologies or products  
- Improving public health and healthcare delivery  
- Enhancing education and lifelong learning systems  
- Creating inclusive, accessible experiences for diverse users  
- Streamlining operations and increasing organizational efficiency  
- Leading and managing teams through change and growth  
- Building ethical frameworks for AI, data, and privacy issues  
- Designing user-centered products and services  
- Scaling startups or growing established businesses sustainably  
- Innovating business models and market strategies  
- Navigating regulatory, legal, and policy challenges  
- Strengthening community development and local economies  
- Solving complex, ambiguous problems requiring cross-disciplinary approaches  
- Improving supply chain resilience and risk management  
- Fostering mental health, wellbeing, and workplace culture  
- Enhancing customer experience and stakeholder relationships  
- Driving research and evidence-based decision making  
- Tackling poverty, homelessness, and affordable housing issues

Question: Where and how can I make a meaningful contribution with my degree?
Answer:
Where:
- Private sector/industry (companies applying technical, managerial, or creative skills)
- Nonprofits and community organizations
- Government and public policy agencies
- Research and higher‑education institutions
- Startups and social enterprises
- Healthcare and human services
- Environmental and climate initiatives
- Arts, culture, and creative industries
- International development and NGOs
- Freelance/consulting across sectors

How:
- Identify the challenges you care about and match them to roles and sectors
- Apply the knowledge and transferable skills from your degree as a foundation
- Use design thinking to explore problems, prototype ideas, and iterate solutions
- Take small risks: do informational interviews, internships, volunteer roles, or short projects
- Network and build connections to learn pathways and uncover opportunities
- Build a portfolio or body of work that demonstrates impact and skills
- Practice talking about your skills and story with confidence
- Use career services and available resources to research options and prepare materials
- Stay curious and open‑minded; be willing to adapt as your interests and the world change
- Focus on where your values, talents, and the work that needs doing intersect

Question: What does taking small risks in career exploration look like?
Answer:
- Request informational interviews or coffee chats with professionals
- Attend networking events, career fairs, or alumni panels
- Reach out to professionals on LinkedIn with a brief message/question
- Volunteer for a short-term project or community role
- Take an internship, co-op, or part-time job outside your comfort zone
- Shadow someone in a role you’re curious about for a day
- Apply for jobs you’re interested in even if you don’t meet every requirement
- Try freelance, contract, or gig work to gain experience
- Join a student club or take on a small leadership role
- Run a short personal or side project to build skills and portfolio
- Enroll in a workshop or short course to learn a new skill
- Ask for feedback or mentorship from a professor, supervisor, or peer
- Practice pitching your skills by doing mock interviews or presentations
- Experiment with alternative roles or industries through informational research

Question: How does action-taking lead to discovery and new possibilities?
Answer:
- Taking small risks produces real-world feedback that reveals interests, strengths, and opportunities.  
- Action starts an iterative discovery process: try, learn, adjust, and expand possibilities.  
- Doing work builds flexibility and creativity, making you open to more pathways.  
- Networking and informational conversations uncovered by action reveal hidden roles and clearer direction.  
- Testing roles or projects exposes transferable skills and realistic fits you couldn’t predict from theory alone.  
- Applying for jobs and engaging with employers shows who’s hiring and what’s valued now.  
- Practicing how you talk about yourself increases confidence and attracts opportunities.  
- Exploration through action helps you identify the problems you want to tackle and where you can contribute.

Question: Why do Career and Volunteer Services often get asked "What can I do with my degree?"
Answer:
- Because many students think their degree will define their identity and predict their job prospects.  
- Because some believe fixed planning guarantees success and expect a linear career path.  
- Because students expect that identifying an “ideal” career will determine the next five years.  
- Because uncertainty about the future (technology, economy, climate, political and societal change) makes career outcomes unclear.  
- Because students themselves change—their values, interests, abilities, and goals evolve.  
- Because they want to understand practical ways to apply their skills and what career possibilities their degree opens.

Question: How can I use the knowledge and skills from my studies as a foundation for my career?
Answer:
- Inventory your transferable skills (research, analysis, communication, teamwork, problem-solving, technical tools) and map them to job tasks.
- Translate coursework into concrete outcomes (projects, methodologies, software, lab techniques) you can show or discuss.
- Create a portfolio of class projects, papers, prototypes, presentations, or a GitHub/website to demonstrate your work.
- Seek hands-on experience: internships, co-ops, part-time roles, volunteer work, or research assistantships.
- Conduct informational interviews and network to learn how employers apply your skills in different roles and industries.
- Use design-thinking: prototype career options, run short experiments (temp roles, freelance, shadowing) and iterate based on feedback.
- Tailor your resume and cover letters to highlight relevant skills and measurable outcomes for each role you apply to.
- Practice your personal pitch and storytelling that combines your major, skills, values, and what you want to contribute.
- Fill skill gaps with targeted courses, workshops, certifications, or self-directed learning.
- Find mentors, ask for feedback, and use campus career services and alumni connections to accelerate growth.
- Apply widely and stay open-minded—use early roles to gain experience and refine your career direction.
- Regularly reflect on your values, interests, and strengths to align future learning and job choices.

Question: What external factors might influence my ability to follow a career plan?
Answer:
Technology
The state of the economy
Climate
Political changes
Societal changes

Question: How might my values, interests, and sense of self change over time?
Answer:
- They evolve as you gain new knowledge, skills, experiences, and feedback from coursework, work, and life events.
- External forces (technology, economy, climate, politics, societal shifts) change what work is possible and what you value.
- Exploring careers, taking risks, and networking expose you to new possibilities that reshape interests and goals.
- Personal growth (maturity, changing responsibilities, relationships) shifts priorities and life goals.
- Reflection and iteration (design thinking, info interviews, trial jobs) refine what feels meaningful and attainable.
- Your major becomes one part of your identity rather than its definition, allowing broader interests to emerge.
- Expectations adjust as you learn what work actually looks like; early assumptions often give way to new aspirations.
- Values may be clarified or reprioritized as you encounter ethical, environmental, or social issues that matter to you.
- Confidence and how you talk about yourself develop, changing how you see your strengths and career fit.
- Situations are temporary; openness and flexibility let your sense of self adapt to new roles and opportunities.

Question: How do I balance what I want to do with the work that needs doing in the world?
Answer:
1. Clarify your values, interests, strengths, and talents — what matters to you and what energizes you.  
2. Research the work that needs doing: industries, societal problems, and labour-market trends.  
3. Map the overlap: identify roles and problems where your strengths meet real-world needs.  
4. Use design thinking: frame questions like “What challenges do I want to tackle?” and prototype solutions.  
5. Take small risks and iterate: do informational interviews, short projects, volunteering, or internships.  
6. Build transferable skills (communication, problem‑solving, collaboration, tech) that apply across roles.  
7. Network and seek mentors to get clues, feedback, and opportunities you wouldn’t see alone.  
8. Choose experiences that let you make contributions now while keeping options open for change.  
9. Practice talking about your story and impact clearly so employers and collaborators understand your value.  
10. Stay curious and adaptable—reassess periodically and adjust as your interests, the world, and opportunities evolve.

Question: What does the text mean by expectations looking different from the truth?
Answer:
- Because the future is uncertain (technology, the economy, climate, political and social change can alter job prospects).  
- Because you will change over time—your values, interests, abilities, and sense of self may shift.  
- Because a major or early plan doesn’t rigidly determine your career; degrees open multiple possibilities.  
- Because career paths aren’t linear and fixed planning often won’t match how things actually unfold.  
- It doesn’t mean worse—just different; you’ll need to adapt, explore, and reassess.

Question: How can the “graphic” mentioned help tell the story of career expectations versus reality?
Answer:
- Visualize the gap between early expectations and actual career paths (e.g., what you thought at 17 vs. where you are at 25).  
- Show multiple possible routes rather than a single linear career trajectory.  
- Illustrate iterative stages of exploration (design thinking, research, networking, skill-building, applying).  
- Highlight external factors (technology, economy, politics, climate) that alter career outcomes.  
- Normalize change and uncertainty by showing that situations are temporary and paths can shift.  
- Emphasize transferable skills and that a major opens diverse opportunities, not just one job.  
- Encourage small risk-taking and action (informational interviews, networking) by mapping steps to take.  
- Provide clues and decision points to help prioritize choices and next moves.  
- Connect viewers to resources (prepare, job opportunities, career services) for practical follow-through.

Question: Do I identify as focused on a particular career, open to many possibilities, or unsure?
Answer:
Focused on a particular career or pathway.
Have many possibilities.
Very unsure and open to ideas.

Question: Why are all situations considered good and temporary in career development?
Answer:
- Because careers and life aren’t linear — roles and paths change over time.  
- Because external factors (technology, economy, climate, politics) make the future uncertain and circumstances shift.  
- Because your values, interests, abilities and identity will evolve as you grow.  
- Because each situation offers learning and stepping-stones, not a permanent definition of you.  
- Because multiple options exist and you can revisit or change choices as you gain experience.  
- Because taking small risks and iterating creates new possibilities, so the current state won’t last.

Question: What does it mean that careers and life aren’t linear?
Answer:
- Career paths don’t follow a single predictable route; people change roles, interests, and goals over time.
- External forces (technology, economy, politics, climate) and personal growth create uncertainty and new possibilities.
- Your major or initial plan won’t rigidly define you; it’s a foundation among many options.
- Progress is iterative—explore, take small risks, learn, and adapt rather than expecting a straight line.

Question: What is Design Thinking and how does it apply to defining my career?
Answer:
Design Thinking — definition
- A human-centered, solution-based, iterative approach for solving complex, unclear problems. Core phases: empathize (understand people/needs), define (frame the problem), ideate (generate many options), prototype (build low‑cost experiments), and test (learn and refine).

How it applies to defining your career
- Treat your career as a design challenge: you don’t need a single fixed answer; you explore and iterate.
- Empathize with yourself and the market: clarify your values, skills, interests, and the needs/opportunities in workplaces.
- Define a focused question (e.g., “What kinds of work let me solve X problem and use Y skills?”).
- Ideate broadly: list many possible roles, industries, and pathways without judging them.
- Prototype quickly and cheaply: do info interviews, short internships, volunteer roles, freelance projects, part‑time jobs, or shadowing to test options.
- Test and learn: reflect on what you enjoyed, what fit, and what didn’t; use that feedback to refine your next experiments.
- Repeat iteratively: small risks and continual learning build clarity, flexibility, and new possibilities for your career.

Question: What small risks should I take when developing my career (e.g., information interviews)?
Answer:
- Request informational interviews with professionals in fields of interest
- Attend networking events, career fairs, or industry meetups and start conversations
- Send cold emails or LinkedIn messages asking for advice or a brief chat
- Volunteer, take short-term internships, co-ops, or contract roles
- Apply for jobs that slightly exceed your current qualifications
- Take on stretch projects or extra responsibilities in class or work
- Job-shadow someone for a day or week
- Ask someone to mentor you or provide career feedback
- Share your work publicly (LinkedIn posts, portfolio, blog) or present at events
- Start a side project, freelance gig, or small consulting work
- Enroll in a course or certification outside your comfort zone
- Join and take a leadership role in a student club or professional association
- Request candid feedback on your resume, cover letter, or interview performance
- Negotiate salary, title, or responsibilities when offered a role
- Try short-term relocation, exchange, or remote work opportunities

Question: How can networking and building connections help my career exploration?
Answer:
- Provide information about different careers, roles, and day-to-day realities through conversations and informational interviews
- Reveal hidden job opportunities and referrals not advertised publicly
- Connect you with mentors and advisors who offer guidance, feedback, and career vision
- Help you test and refine interests by exposing you to diverse pathways and perspectives
- Build your professional reputation and increase chances of being recommended for roles
- Offer concrete leads to internships, volunteer roles, projects, or work experiences
- Help you practice self-presentation and interviewing skills, boosting confidence
- Expand your knowledge of industry trends, required skills, and employer expectations
- Create collaborative opportunities that develop new skills and portfolio work
- Turn exploratory curiosity into iterative action—small risks that lead to discovery and new possibilities

Question: Why is learning to talk about myself with confidence important for my career?
Answer:
- It’s a core life skill that helps you express who you are and what you offer.  
- It develops your professional voice and personal brand.  
- It lets you clearly communicate your skills, knowledge, values, and talents.  
- It improves networking and relationship-building opportunities.  
- It increases confidence in interviews, information interviews, and employer conversations.  
- It helps you articulate a compelling career narrative and body of work.  
- It enables you to advocate for yourself (roles, projects, salary, growth).  
- It makes it easier to take small risks and pursue new opportunities.  
- It boosts visibility and employability across multiple career possibilities.

Question: How can I clean up my online presence to attract career opportunities, based on the site?

- Remove or make private unprofessional or irrelevant posts, photos, and comments.
- Adjust privacy settings on social platforms to limit public access to personal content.
- Update and optimize professional profiles (e.g., LinkedIn) with clear, consistent information.
- Curate and showcase relevant work through a content portfolio to demonstrate skills and projects.
- Align your online content and messaging with your career goals and the roles you seek.
- Use professional branding (photo, headline, summary) and include contact details so employers can reach you.

- Work‑Study/research-based student projects — supplemental income for students with demonstrated financial need.  
- Departmental on‑campus jobs — SFU Library, Residence & Housing, SFU Bookstore, SFU Dining, Academics First Tutoring (posted seasonally).  
- Recreation positions — aquatics, climbing, fitness, instructional programs, promotion & marketing, rec sports.  
- Academic positions — Teaching Assistant, Research Assistant, Lab Assistant, Tutor‑Markers.  
- Part‑time/short‑term/continuing campus positions and student society roles (leadership, essential services).  
- Student media and clubs — opportunities with groups like The Peak and CJSF Radio; join 200+ SFU clubs for leadership experience.  
- On/near‑campus retail and food outlets — Renaissance Coffee, Blenz, UniverCity, Central City Shopping Centre.  
- Job search engines and boards — Indeed, LinkedIn, Job Bank, WorkBC.  
- Volunteer platforms — GetInvolved, MeaningfulWork, Volunteer BC, CharityVillage, Idealist, CanadaHelps (search by interest/skills).  
- National/international listings — nonprofit job databases across Canada and worldwide; UN/EU/International Organization vacancies.  
- Government programs — Canada Summer Jobs (employers hire youth 15–30 for summer), Federal student hiring programs (various eligibility and formats).  
- Entrepreneurship and research supports — VentureLabs and national non‑profits that support grad students/postdocs (check program eligibility).  
- Career supports — SFU Explore and Prepare resources; book Career Peer appointment to review applications.  
- Contact SFU Career Services — Phone: 778.782.3106; Email: careers@sfu.ca; Instagram: @sfu.career

Question: Does my choice of major define who I am?
Answer: No — your major is only one part of your story; your skills, talents, interests, values, and how you want to be in the world also shape who you are and the careers open to you.

Question: What other factors besides my major contribute to my story?
Answer:
Skills and knowledge
Talents
Interests
What is important to you (values)
How you want to be in the world
The challenges you want to tackle
Where and how you want to make a contribution

Question: Why is it important to consider skills, talents, interests, and values when planning a career?
Answer:
- They reveal what you’re good at and enjoy, helping match careers to your strengths and interests.
- They complement your major to give a fuller picture of career possibilities beyond a single label.
- They help identify meaningful work by clarifying what’s important to you and how you want to be in the world.
- They expand and diversify potential career paths, increasing flexibility as your goals evolve.
- They enable more informed, confident, and motivating career decisions.
- They guide actionable exploration and skills development toward roles where you can contribute and grow.

Question: What is the value of a major in terms of career possibilities?
Answer: The value of your major is in the multiple career possibilities open to you.

Question: Should I explore career options related to other majors as well as my own?
Answer: Yes. Exploring career options related to other majors expands your possibilities, helps you stay open-minded as interests change, and lets you use resources (LinkedIn/SFU Alumni tool, Career Educator appointments) to make informed decisions.

Question: When should I start exploring career options related to my major?
Answer: Now — start exploring career options as early as possible.

Question: What attitude should I have while exploring career options now?
Answer:
Curious
Open-minded
Watchful for clues
Inquisitive (ask questions)
Committed to taking action
Confident and excited

Question: How can I watch for clues to help make informed initial career decisions?
Answer:
- Be curious and open-minded
- Notice your skills, knowledge, talents, interests, and values (what’s important to you and how you want to be in the world)
- Explore career options related to your major and other majors
- Research career outcomes using program pages and LinkedIn (SFU Alumni tool)
- Review alumni job titles and evidence-based career resources
- Make an appointment with a Career Educator
- Ask questions
- Use the career resources provided and commit to taking action
- Remember some paths may require further education or experience

- Be curious

Question: How might my degree help me identify challenges I want to tackle?
Answer:
- Reveals the skills, knowledge and talents you can apply to real-world problems
- Clarifies your interests, values and what matters to you, guiding which challenges feel meaningful
- Exposes you to multiple career paths and sectors where those challenges exist
- Encourages curiosity and open-minded exploration to uncover problems that excite you
- Alumni career outcomes (e.g., LinkedIn SFU Alumni tool) show job titles/sectors and the challenges grads address
- Joint, double or major–minor combinations broaden the range of issues you can tackle
- Career Educators and program resources help you match your degree to challenge areas and plan next steps
- Practical experiences (projects, internships, labs, practicums) let you test and identify real-world challenges
- Researching program and industry options helps you make informed choices about where to contribute

Question: How can I discover where and how I want to make a contribution with my degree?
Answer:
- Reflect on your skills, knowledge, talents, interests, values, and what matters to you.  
- Be curious and open-minded; watch for clues about what energizes you.  
- Explore career options related to your major and other majors to expand possibilities.  
- Research career outcomes using program pages and the LinkedIn SFU Alumni tool.  
- Review SFU alumni job titles and evidence-based career resources for real examples.  
- Make an appointment with a Career Educator for personalized guidance.  
- Ask questions through faculty, instructors, and career services.  
- Conduct informational interviews and job-shadow or network with alumni and professionals.  
- Gain practical experience via internships, co-ops, volunteer roles, research, or part-time jobs.  
- Take electives, join clubs, and pursue projects that test different interests and skills.  
- Create and update a resume/LinkedIn profile to reflect evolving goals and experiences.  
- Commit to action, iterate based on what you learn, and adjust your path as you grow.

Question: What does the Student Learning Commons provide?
Answer: Expert and friendly help with academic writing, learning, and study strategies — in an environment of collaboration, discussion, and peer learning.

Question: What types of help does the Student Learning Commons offer?
Answer:
Expert, friendly help with academic writing, learning, and study strategies in a collaborative, discussion- and peer-learning environment.
A time-management tool: type in your assignment due date to break down writing assignments into steps.
The SLC Writing Contest is open for submissions.
One-on-one writing and learning consultations are available.
Programs to build confidence and self-expression — register now.
Services available at both Surrey and Burnaby campuses during the exam period.

Question: What is a course load?
Answer: The total number of units determined by the courses you're enrolled in for a given term.

Question: What does having the "perfect" course load mean?
Answer: Finding a course load that gives you balance in life both on and off-campus while you pursue your academic, professional, and personal goals—choosing what’s right for your needs rather than a “perfect” number.

Question: How should I determine the right course load for my needs?
Answer:
- Clarify your learning objectives and degree requirements (units, prerequisites, and timeline for completion)
- Balance academic, professional and personal goals so your course load supports life on and off campus
- Assess your current life circumstances (work, family, health, commute) and realistic weekly time for study
- Start with a manageable number of units and allow flexibility to adjust as your needs evolve
- Give yourself time before enrolling each term to reassess priorities and plans
- Consult an Academic Advisor for personalized guidance and to see the bigger picture

Question: Why should I allow flexibility in my course plans before enrolling each term?
Answer:
- Because your learning objectives, educational path, and life circumstances can change over time.  
- Because plans for degree completion may shift, requiring different courses or pacing.  
- Because flexibility helps you find a balanced course load that supports academic, professional, and personal goals.  
- Because giving yourself time allows better decision‑making before enrolling each term.  
- Because advisors can help you adjust plans to fit the bigger picture.

Question: How can my learning objectives, educational path and life circumstances affect my course load?
Answer:
Learning objectives:
- Aiming for deeper mastery (research, capstone, honors) may require more advanced, time‑intensive courses or fewer courses to focus on depth.
- Seeking breadth or multiple minors/certificates may increase the number of courses per term.
- Needing specific skills (labs, studios, internships) can change the type and workload of courses you choose.

Educational path:
- Degree requirements, major/minor changes or adding credentials can raise or shift your course load to meet required credits.
- Course sequencing and prerequisites may force lighter or heavier terms depending on what’s available when.
- Transfer credits, co-op or study‑abroad plans can accelerate or delay course load in certain terms.

Life circumstances:
- Employment, caregiving, health or financial responsibilities may require a reduced (part‑time) course load.
- Personal commitments, commuting or relocation affect how many and what kind of courses you can manage.
- Mental health or unexpected events may necessitate flexibility and temporary adjustments to course load.

Question: Who can help me navigate course loads as they relate to my goals?
Answer: An Academic Advisor

Question: How do I book an appointment with an Academic Advisor?
Answer: Book an appointment

Question: What should I consider when planning my course load?
Answer:
- The total number of units you’ll be enrolled in for the term
- Balance between on‑campus and off‑campus life
- Your academic, professional and personal goals
- Your current learning objectives and educational path
- Evolving life circumstances that may affect capacity
- Flexibility in your plans (allow time to adjust before enrolling)
- Degree completion timeline and how the load fits it
- Consult an Academic Advisor to see the bigger picture

Question: Why is planning my course schedule important?
Answer:
- Ensure you can enroll in required and prerequisite courses and avoid being blocked from progress
- Manage academic progress and maintain the minimum GPA for Good Academic Standing
- Balance course load with time management, study habits, and personal/family responsibilities
- Plan tuition and expenses to avoid financial strain and optimize time to degree (use the Cost Calculator)
- Secure desired courses and avoid schedule conflicts
- Time degree completion to meet program requirements efficiently
- Incorporate work (e.g., Work‑Study) and experiential opportunities without overloading
- Get program-specific guidance from Academic/Faculty Advisors

Question: What problems can occur if I don’t plan my schedule?
Answer:
- Unable to enrol in required, prerequisite, or desired courses (full classes or scheduling conflicts)
- Delayed degree completion
- Higher tuition costs or increased financial burden
- Poor academic performance or lowered GPA
- Risk of falling out of Good Academic Standing
- Overcommitment from taking an unmanageable course load
- Conflicts with work, extracurriculars, or personal obligations
- Missed Work‑Study, co‑op, or other experiential opportunities

- Consultation with an Academic Advisor

Question: How can tuition fees influence my decision on course load and time to degree completion?
Answer:
- A heavier course load raises your immediate term tuition and out‑of‑pocket costs, which may strain your budget or require loans/extra work.  
- Taking more courses per term can shorten time to degree and may reduce total tuition and living costs overall.  
- Spreading courses over more terms lowers per‑term expenses but can increase total tuition, living costs and delay graduation.  
- Full‑time vs part‑time status (and related fee structures) affects eligibility for financial aid, scholarships and benefits, so it influences how many courses you can afford to take.  
- Delaying graduation risks future tuition increases and extended living/expense commitments.  
- Use a cost calculator and budgeting (and consider work‑study or other income) to compare short‑term affordability versus long‑term cost savings.

Answer: Use the Cost Calculator to estimate your expenses each term and help budget for the school year.

- Family or caregiver responsibilities
- Childcare needs
- Commute or travel time
- Health and medical appointments; mental‑wellness needs
- Extracurriculars, clubs, sports and social commitments
- Volunteering, internships, co‑op or practicum placements
- Financial obligations and budgeting demands
- Personal commitments and hobbies
- Required time for sleep, self‑care and effective study time

- Map your degree’s transferrable skills (research, analysis, communication, project management) to job roles and industries. Use job postings and LinkedIn to identify typical entry roles, required skills, and career pathways; consider internships, volunteer roles or short-term contracts to gain relevant experience.

How can I prepare for what's next?
- Clarify goals (short- and long-term), update your résumé/CV and LinkedIn, build targeted skills via courses or volunteer work, network and do informational interviews, apply strategically to jobs with tailored applications, and practice interviewing (mock interviews available by referral). Book a 1:1 career appointment or attend drop-ins for personalized guidance.

Should I pursue further training or attend graduate school?
- Decide based on career goals: if your target role requires advanced credentials or research experience, grad school may be appropriate. Consider cost, time, career outcomes, alternatives (professional certificates, work experience, apprenticeships), and opportunities to try relevant roles first. Consult a Career Educator to weigh options and plan application/timelines.

Question: What is the difference between a resume and a curriculum vitae (CV)?
Answer:
Ask yourself (quick checklist)
- What exact roles do I want long-term, and do those roles explicitly require a graduate degree or professional credential?
- What skills or experience am I missing that prevent me from getting those roles now?
- Do I prefer academic/research work or applied/professional work?
- Can I afford tuition and time away from paid work? Are there funding/scholarship options?
- How strong is my academic record for admission? Do I have potential referees?
- Do I need to switch fields, or deepen expertise in my current field?
- Am I ready for 1–3+ years of full-time study, or would part-time/online study be better?

How to interpret your answers
- If your target jobs require a master’s/PhD or research credentials (e.g., academia, certain clinical/research roles), prioritize graduate school.
- If employers value applied skills, certifications, or hands‑on experience (e.g., tech, project management, many industry roles), short courses, certificates, bootcamps, or targeted training + work experience are often higher ROI.
- If you’re unsure, gain 6–12 months of relevant work or volunteer experience first — this clarifies interests and strengthens future applications.
- If funding, time, or admission competitiveness are major barriers, consider part‑time/online graduate programs or micro‑credentials as intermediate steps.
- If you have a strong research interest and potential supervisors at programs you like, that’s a good sign to apply.

Alternatives to immediate grad school
- Professional certificates, microcredentials, bootcamps
- Short courses and online learning (Coursera, edX, industry providers)
- Internships, co‑ops, volunteer roles, contract work
- Professional designations or licensure relevant to your field
- Part‑time or bridging master’s programs, or post‑baccalaureate diplomas

Practical comparison points (use when choosing)
- Cost and funding (stipend, scholarship, employer sponsorship)
- Time to completion and opportunity cost of lost earnings
- Career outcomes and typical salaries after completion
- Admission requirements and your competitiveness
- Mode of delivery (in‑person vs online vs part‑time)
- Networking and experiential learning opportunities

Next steps (actionable)
- Scan job ads in your target field to see what credentials employers list.
- Do 3–5 informational interviews with people in roles you want.
- Try a short online course to test interest and build skills.
- If considering research grad school, contact potential supervisors and ask about projects and funding.
- If considering professional training, compare curricula, industry recognition, and alumni outcomes.
- Book a 1:1 with a Career Educator at SFU (myExperience) to review goals, CV, and options — bring your CV and sample job postings. You can also call 778-782-3106 or email careers@sfu.ca.

If you want, tell me: your field, current level (UG/PG), work experience, and target roles — I can give a tailored recommendation.

What are my options for the future?
- Enter the workforce (full‑time, part‑time, contract), pursue internships or co‑ops, take volunteer or short‑term roles to build experience, start your own venture, or apply to professional programs or graduate school. You can also pursue professional certifications or specialized training relevant to your field.

What can I do with my degree?
- Most degrees open multiple pathways: industry roles, public sector, nonprofit work, research or academic roles (with a CV/grad school), consulting, policy, or entrepreneurial work. Transferable skills (communication, analysis, project management) let you pivot into related fields—use career exploration and informational interviews to map degree to roles.

How can I prepare for what’s next?
- Reflect on your interests, values, skills and experiences.
- Research occupations and labour market information; do informational interviews.
- Gain relevant experience (work, volunteer, projects, internships).
- Build application materials (resume, cover letter, CV) and a LinkedIn profile.
- Practice interviewing (mock interviews where available) and network to find opportunities.
- Book a 1:1 career appointment via myExperience or attend drop‑ins/workshops for tailored guidance. Bring your resume and any job postings to appointments.

Should I pursue further training or attend graduate school?
- Base the decision on your career goals: is a graduate degree required or will it significantly improve prospects or salary in your target field?
- Consider alternatives (professional certificates, short courses, work experience) that may achieve the same goal faster or cheaper.
- Weigh costs, time, return on investment, and personal readiness.
- Get advising: speak with faculty, alumni in your field, and a Career Educator to make an informed choice.

How to access SFU Career support
- Free, confidential career guidance for undergrads, grads and recent alumni (up to one year after graduation).
- 50‑minute 1:1 appointments in person (all campuses) or via Zoom; book/manage on myExperience. Drop‑ins and shorter sessions are first come, first served.
- Bring a copy of your resume/CV (physical or digital) and any job postings to appointments. Mock interviews require referral from a Career Educator and must be booked through the Front Desk.
- Contact: Phone 778‑782‑3106 (Mon–Fri 9:00–16:30) or careers@sfu.ca; Instagram @sfu.career.

Resume: A concise, targeted summary of your skills, experience and achievements tailored for industry or non‑academic job applications.

Curriculum Vitae (CV): A comprehensive, detailed record of your education, academic accomplishments, research, publications and credentials used for academic or research‑based positions.

Question: Where are in-person appointments offered?
Answer:
There are many paths: entering the workforce in roles that match your skills, doing internships/co‑op or volunteer work to gain experience, pursuing professional training or certificates, applying to graduate or professional schools, starting a business or freelance work, or exploring research/academic opportunities. Use career exploration (self‑assessment, informational interviews, job market research) to narrow options that fit your interests and values.

You can leverage your degree in multiple sectors—private industry, non‑profits, government, education, research, or entrepreneurship—depending on your major and transferable skills. Translate coursework and experiences into concrete skills on your resume, pursue relevant experience (work, volunteer, projects), and target roles where your knowledge and strengths align.

Prepare by clarifying goals, building a tailored resume/CV and cover letter, optimizing your LinkedIn, gaining relevant experience (volunteer, part‑time, internships, projects), practicing interviews or doing mock interviews, networking and informational interviewing, and developing any technical or professional skills employers seek. Use job search strategies (targeted applications, employer research) and seek feedback from career services.

Whether to pursue further training or graduate school depends on your career goals, required credentials in your field, financial/time considerations, and what you’ll gain versus entering the workforce first. Research program outcomes, speak with advisors and professionals in the field, consider alternatives (certificates, short courses, work experience), and use a career educator to weigh pros and cons.

Question: When does the Provincial Attestation Letter (PAL) requirement start?
Answer: January 22, 2025

Question: Which study permit applications require a PAL starting January 22, 2025?
Answer: Most study permit applications — including applicants for graduate programs and those changing schools (e.g., high school to post‑secondary or transferring DLIs).

Question: Are students applying for graduate programs required to have a PAL?
Answer: Yes — starting Jan 22, 2025, most graduate program applicants are required to have a PAL (exemptions may apply).

Question: Do students changing schools (for example high school to post-secondary or transferring DLIs) need a PAL?
Answer: Yes. Starting January 22, 2025, a PAL is required for most study permit applications, including students changing schools (e.g., high school to post‑secondary or transferring DLIs).

Question: What does IRCC require in terms of pursuing studies while at SFU?
Answer: Actively pursue your studies while at SFU.

Question: How often is SFU required to report the enrolment status of international students to IRCC?
Answer: Twice a year.

Question: How does my enrolment at SFU affect my ability to work in Canada?
Answer:
Your enrolment determines whether you meet your study permit conditions (IRCC requires you to actively pursue your studies), and SFU reports international students’ enrolment status to IRCC twice a year — this reporting can affect your eligibility to work in Canada.  
Contact an International Student Advisor/Immigration Specialist for guidance.

Question: How does my enrolment at SFU affect my ability to study or stay in Canada?
Answer:
- Your enrolment determines compliance with your study permit — IRCC requires you to actively pursue your studies.  
- SFU is required to report your enrolment status to IRCC twice a year.  
- Your enrolment status affects your ability to work, continue studying, and remain in Canada; losing enrolment may jeopardize your study permit/immigration status.  
- Contact an International Student Advisor / Immigration Specialist for assistance.

Question: What is the difference between fixed and variable costs for students?
Answer:
Fixed costs: Expenses that don’t change very often and are predictable term-to-term (more “non‑negotiable” in your budget).  
Variable costs: Expenses that fluctuate based on usage or consumption, are less predictable, and can go up or down.
